Hebrew text

Text auf Deutsch

Testo in italiano


My name is Usumain (Ismail) Baraka. I need your help in order to finance my undergraduate studies in political science, so that I can pursue my dream of being in the front line to end conflicts in diplomatic ways. This is my story:

I was born in 1994 in Dirhata, a small village in Darfur, in the western part of Sudan. In 2003, when the Janjaweed militias came to kill all the males, I was nine years old. My father and older brother were shot dead. I was saved only because my mother dressed me as a girl. The killers hit her and asked where her other sons were, but she said she only had daughters left: these were my sisters and I. The militias burned the house, waiting outside to make sure we were dead. My mother told us to cry and shout. The militias thus thought we were dying and left the place. We escaped the burning house and left the village. On the way, we spotted my fatherʼs body, and few meters ahead my brotherʼs. We arrived to a UN refugees camp in Chad, in which we lived together until 2007. At that point I decided I could no longer live in the hard conditions of the camp. Rather than going back to our village and fight, I wanted to study. 

I realized we could gain back our homes by studying, by understanding the political situation and how it evolved, and by coming up with non-violent ways to make peace and end the genocide. 

I left the UN camp when I was only thirteen, leaving behind my beloved ones.

I crossed Chad and reached Libya. In the city of Bengazi I started learning English and I worked in a shop, earning some money for living. After a year and a half I moved with a friend to Egypt, where studying was cheap, according to what I had heard. But the Egyptian and Sudanese governments collaborated to send the Darfur people back, only to face either limitless imprisonment or death. I had to leave Egypt.

One day, on the television, I watched a documentary about the Shoah, the Jewish Holocaust. The only thing I knew about the Jews was that Israel is the only Jewish country in the world. Watching the documentary, I learned about the Jewish people's past, about their being freed from slavery in Egypt, about the persecutions and discrimination they have suffered over the centuries until they were able to found their own country and live there freely. I could identify myself with this story and I had no doubt that the Jewish people would sympathize with my and my people's story: I had to go to Israel.

I got in touch with someone who smuggled migrants over the border to Israel. We were twelve people in the group, including me and my friend. At night, we crawled towards the Israeli part, trying to avoid the Egyptian soldiers. Then, suddenly, someone in the group got panicked: he jumped to his feet and started shouting. Three bullets in the head, shot by the soldiers, killed him on the spot. The soldiers now came in our direction and we had no choice but to start running towards the Israeli border fence and hope that the bullets would not hit us. We dropped everything we had and ran, ran ran. My friend and I ran as fast as we could, holding hands. On the way, another man in the group was shot dead, followed by his fellow who came back to assist him. The rest of us reached the border fence and climbed on it. The Israeli soldiers gave us water and treated our wounds.

I was taken to a prison, where I spent a month and a half in the adults section. When I was released, I got a temporary visa and moved to Tel Aviv, where I lived without any clear purpose. But I kept learning English. In 2010 I moved to Yemin Orde, a youth village that provides migrants and refugees with a place to live in and with the possibility to study. I felt safe for the first time since I had arrived to Israel. I learned Hebrew and did high school there. In 2014, I finished my exams. Since then, I have been volunteering in the village, trying to give back at least some of what I have received there so generously.

Now I would like to make the next step and acquire higher education. I have already been accepted to undergraduate studies in two Israeli institutions, between which I have to choose: the prestigious Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy and Strategy at the Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (IDC) and the first degree in Politics and Government at the Tel Aviv-Yafo Academy.

Studying is the reason I why left the camp in Chad. Despite all the difficulties I encountered ever since, I have never forgotten this goal and dream. 

I learned hard to get good grades in high school, and also the acceptance to the two institutions of higher education is the fruit of hard work. I want to have a degree in political science and international relations. I want to go back to my country and help my people live in peace on their land. I want to build a bridge between my first homeland, Africa, and my second one, Israel – the country of the people who I am still convinced can best identify with my situation, since they had precisely the same unfortunate experience.

While I am pursuing my goals, I am not forgetting my brothers and sisters who have gone through the same hell like me. As I have been doing so far, I will keep helping other refugees who live in Israel and have difficulties, and visiting inmates in detention camps for refugees. I am also not forgetting the youth village that has given me the possibility to live well and study. I am continuing to volunteer in the various facilities of the village.

The only thing that separates me from a first degree are the fees. I would be endlessly grateful to have your support, so that I can accomplish my goal, graduate successfully and contribute in peaceful ways to end conflicts that have already demanded too many lives.


שמי אוסומעין (איסמעיל) בארכה. אני זקוק לעזרתך כדי לממן את לימודי התואר הראשון שלי במדעי המדינה, כדי שאוכל להגשים את חלומי ולהילחם כדי לסיים קונפליקטים בדרכים דיפלומטיות. זה הסיפור שלי.

נולדתי בשנת 1994 בדירהטה, כפר קטן במחוז דארפור שבמערב סודאן. ב-2003, כאשר מיליציות הג'נג'אווידים באו להרוג את כל הגברים והילדים הזכרים, הייתי בן תשע. אבי ואחי הגדול נורו למוות. אני ניצלתי רק בזכות אמי שהלבישה אותי כמו ילדה. הרוצחים הכו אותה ושאלו אותה איפה הבנים האחרים שלה, אבל היא אמרה שנותרו לה רק בנות: אלו היו אחיותיי ואני. אנשי המיליציה הציתו את הבית באש, וחיכו בחוץ כדי לוודא שנשרפנו. אמי אמרה לנו לצעוק חזק ולבכות, ככה אנשי המיליציה חשבו שעמדנו למות והלכו משם. הצלחנו לברוח מהבית הבוער ועזבנו את הכפר. בדרך מצאנו את הגופה של אבא שלי, וכמה מטרים הלאה משם את זאת של אחי. הגענו למחנה פליטים של האו"ם בצ'אד, שם גרנו ביחד עד 2007. בנקודה הזאת החלטתי שלא יכולתי יותר לחיות בתנאים הקשים של המחנה. במקום לחזור לכפר שלנו ולהילחם, רציתי ללמוד.

הבנתי שנוכל לקבל את הבית שלנו בחזרה גם על ידי לימודים, על ידי שנלמד ונבין את המצב הפוליטי ואיך הוא התפתח, ועל ידי מציאת דרכים לא אלימות כדי ליצור שלום ולסיים את הטבח.

עזבתי את מחנה האו"ם כשהייתי רק בן 13, והשארתי מאחוריי את שרידי משפחתי האהובה.


חציתי את צ'אד ומשם הגעתי ללוב. בעיר בנגאזי התחלתי ללמוד אנגלית ועבדתי בחנות כדי להרוויח כמה פרוטות. אחרי שנה וחצי עברתי עם חבר למצרים, שם הלימודים היו אמורים להיות יותר נגישים, לפי השמועה. אבל במציאות, הממשל המצרי והסודאני שיתפו פעולה כדי להחזיר את פליטי דארפור לארצם, שם חיכתה להם תקופת זמן לא ידועה בכלא, או מוות. נאלצתי לעזוב את מצרים.

יום אחד צפיתי בטלוויזיה בסרט דוקומנטרי על השואה. הדבר היחיד שידעתי עד אז על היהודים הוא שמדינת ישראל היא המדינה היהודית היחידה בעולם. כשצפיתי בסרט, התוודעתי להיסטוריה של העם היהודי, לשחרורם מהעבדות במצרים, לרדיפות והאפליות שהם סבלו במהלך המאות, עד שהם יכלו להקים לעצמם מדינה משלהם ולחיות בה בחופשיות. הזדהיתי עם הסיפור הזה ולא היה לי ספק שהעם היהודי יזדהה עם הסיפור שלי ושל עמי: הייתי חייב ללכת לישראל.


יצרתי קשר עם מישהו שהבריח אנשים מעבר לגבול, לישראל. היינו 12 אנשים בקבוצה, כולל אני והחבר שלי. בלילה, זחלנו לכיוון החלק הישראלי, נמנעים מהחיילים המצריים. פתאום, מישהו בקבוצה נתקף פאניקה: הוא קפץ על רגליו והתחיל לצעוק. שלושה כדורים בראש, שנורו על ידי החיילים, הרגו אותו במקום. החיילים התחילו עכשיו לבוא לכיווננו, ולא הייתה לנו ברירה אלא לקום ולהתחיל לרוץ לכיוון גדר הגבול הישראלי ולקוות שהכדורים לא יפגעו בנו. זרקנו את כל מה שהיה לנו ורצנו, רצנו בכל כוחנו. חברי ואני רצנו כמה שיותר מהר, מחזיקים ידיים. בדרך, אדם אחר מהקבוצה נורה למוות, ומיד אחריו עוד אחד שחזר אחורה כדי לעזור לו. אנחנו שנשארנו הגענו לגדר וטיפסנו עליה לצד השני. החיילים הישראלים נתנו לנו מים וטיפלו בפצעים שלנו.

נלקחתי לבית כלא, שם שהיתי חודש וחצי במדור של המבוגרים. כשהשתחררתי, קיבלתי ויזה זמנית והגעתי לתל אביב, שם חייתי ללא מטרה ברורה. אבל המשכתי ללמוד אנגלית. בשנת 2010 עברתי לימין אורד, כפר נוער שמעניק למהגרים ופליטים מקום לגור בו ואפשרות ללמוד. בפעם הראשונה מאז הגעתי לישראל הרגשתי בטוח. למדתי עברית ועשיתי לימודי בית ספר תיכון. בשנת 2014 סיימתי בהצלחה את בחינות הבגרות. מאז אני מתנדב בכפר במטרה לתת חזרה ולו מעט מכל מה שקיבלתי שם בנדיבות כה גדולה.


עכשיו אני רוצה לעשות את הצעד הבא ולהתחיל לימודים גבוהים. התקבלתי ללימודי תואר ראשון בשני מוסדות ישראלים, ביניהם אני צריך לבחור: התוכנית היוקרתית בבית הספר לאודר לממשל, דיפלומטיה ואסטרטגיה במרכז הבין תחומי הרצליה ולימודי תואר ראשון בפוליטיקה וממשל באקדמית תל אביב-יפו.

הרצון ללמוד הוא זה שהביא אותי לעזוב את המחנה בצ'אד. למרות כל הקשיים מאז, לא שכחתי את המטרה הזאת – את החלום הזה.

למדתי קשה כדי לקבל ציונים טובים בתיכון, וגם הקבלה לשני המוסדות להשכלה גבוהה היא פרי עבודה קשה. אני רוצה לעשות תואר במדעי המדינה ויחסים בינלאומיים. אני רוצה לחזור לארץ שלי ולעזור לאנשים שלי לחיות בשלום על אדמתם. אני רוצה לבנות גשר בין מולדתי הראשונה, אפריקה, ובין מולדתי השנייה, ישראל – הארץ בה חי העם שאני עדיין משוכנע שהוא היחיד שיכול להזדהות עם המצב שלי, משום שהוא עבר בדיוק את אותה חוויה קשה.


בזמן שאני מגשים את מטרותיי, אני לא שוכח את אחיי ואחיותיי שעברו את אותו הגיהנום כמוני. כמו עד עכשיו, אני אמשיך לעזור לפליטים אחרים שחיים בארץ ושיש להם קשיים, ולבקר את אלו שנמצאים בהסגר. אני גם לא שוכח את כפר הנוער שנתן לי את האפשרות לחיות טוב וללמוד. אני ממשיך להתנדב במוסדות השונים שם.


הדבר היחיד שמפריד ביני ובין התואר הראשון הוא שכר הלימוד. אני אהיה אסיר תודה אם תתמכו בי, כדי שאוכל להגשים את מטרתי: לסיים בהצלחה את לימודי התואר ולתרום בדרכי שלום לסיומם של קונפליקטים שכבר תבעו יותר מדי חיים.


Mein Name ist Usumain (Ismail) Baraka. Ich brauche Ihre Hilfe, damit ich Politikwissenschaften studieren kann. Das Studium bedeutet für mich einen wichtigen Schritt auf meinem Weg, ein Vorreiter ziviler Konfliktlösung zu sein. Im Folgenden meine Geschichte: 

Ich wurde 1994 in Dirhata, einem kleinen Dorf in Darfur im West-Sudan, geboren. Als die Dschandschawid-Milizen 2003 in das Dorf kamen, um alle männlichen Bewohner zu töten, war ich neun Jahre alt. Mein Vater und mein Bruder wurden getötet. Ich überlebte, weil mich meine Mutter als Mädchen verkleidete. Die Mörder schlugen sie und fragten, wo ihre anderen Söhne seien, aber sie antwortete, dass ihr nur noch Töchter geblieben wären: Sie meinte meine Schwestern und mich. Die Miliz zündete das Haus an und wartete vor der Tür, um sicher zu gehen, dass wir tot waren. Meine Mutter sagte uns, dass wir weinen und schreien sollten. So dachte die Miliz, dass wir gerade starben und verließ ihren Posten. Wir flüchteten aus dem brennenden Haus und verließen das Dorf. Auf dem Weg entdeckten wir den Körper meines Vaters, wenige Meter weiter den meines Bruders. Wir erreichten ein UN-Flüchtlingscamp im Tschad, in dem wir bis 2007 lebten. In diesem Jahr entschloss ich mich, die miserablen Zustände in dem Camp nicht länger zu ertragen. Aber anstatt in mein Dorf zurückzukehren und zu kämpfen, wollte ich studieren. 

Denn ich verstand, dass wir unser Zuhause nur zurückgewinnen konnten, wenn wir studierten, wenn wir die politische Situation verstünden und wie es dazu gekommen war. Wenn wir gewaltlose Wege entwickelten, Frieden zu schließen und den Genozid zu beenden.

Darum verließ ich das UN-Flüchtlingscamp. Ich war dreizehn Jahre alt, und ließ meine geliebte  Familie zurück.

Ich durchquerte den Tschad und erreichte Libyen. In Bengazi begann ich, Englisch zu lernen und in einem Shop zu arbeiten, um etwas Geld zu verdienen. Nach anderthalb Jahren zog ich mit einem Freund nach Ägypten, wo es meinen Informationen nach günstig sein sollte zu studieren. Aber die ägyptische und die sudanesische Regierungen hatten eine Übereinkunft getroffen, Menschen aus Darfur zurückzuschicken, wo sie anschließend eine unbegrenzte Gefängnishaft oder der Tod erwarteten. Deshalb musste ich Ägypten verlassen.

Eines Tages sah ich im Fernsehen eine Dokumentation über die Shoah, den jüdischen Holocaust. Das Einzige, was ich bis zu diesem Zeitpunkt über Juden wusste, war, dass Israel das einzige jüdische Land in der Welt ist. Durch die Dokumentation erfuhr ich zum ersten Mal von der Geschichte der Juden, der Befreiung aus der Sklaverei in Ägypten, den anschließenden Jahrtausenden der Verfolgung und Diskriminierung, bis sie schließlich ihr eigenes Land gründen konnten, um in Freiheit zu leben. Ich konnte mich mit dieser Geschichte identifizieren und hatte daher keinen Zweifel, dass die Juden meiner Geschichte und der Geschichte meiner Leute Empathie entgegen bringen würden: Ich musste nach Israel gehen.

Also nahm ich mit jemandem Kontakt auf, der Migranten über die Grenze nach Israel schleuste. Wir waren zwölf Menschen, einschließlich meines Freundes und mir. Eines Nachts krochen wir in Richtung der israelischen Grenze, immer darauf bedacht, die ägyptischen Soldaten zu meiden. Plötzlich geriet einer aus unserer Gruppe in Panik: Er sprang auf und begann zu brüllen. Die drei Kugeln, die ihn in den Kopf trafen, töteten ihn sofort. Die Soldaten bewegten sich nun in unsere Richtung, so dass wir keine Wahl hatten als in Richtung der israelischen Grenze loszulaufen und zu hoffen, dass uns die Kugeln nicht treffen würden. Also ließen wir alles fallen, was wir mit uns genommen hatten und rannten, rannten, rannten. Mein Freund und ich liefen so schnell wir konnten, jeder an der Hand des anderen. Auf dem Weg wurde ein anderer Mann aus unserer Gruppe erschossen, kurz darauf sein Freund, der umgekehrt war, um ihm beizustehen. Der Rest unserer Gruppe erreichte den Grenzzaun und kletterte hinüber. Die israelischen Soldaten gaben uns Wasser und versorgten unsere Wunden. 

Ich wurde in ein Gefängnis gebracht, wo ich eineinhalb Monate im Erwachsenentrakt verblieb. Mit meiner Entlassung erhielt ich ein zeitlich begrenztes Visum und zog nach Tel Aviv, wo ich anschließend ohne eine wirkliche Perspektive lebte. Dort nahm ich meine Englischstudien wieder auf. 2010 zog ich nach Yemin Orde, ein Jugenddorf, das Migrant*innen und Geflüchtete mit einer Unterkunft versorgt und ihnen die Möglichkeit bietet zu studieren. Das erste Mal seit meiner Ankunft in Israel fühlte ich mich sicher. Ich begann, Hebräisch zu lernen und die Schule zu besuchen. 2014 konnte ich meine Schulausbildung abschließen. Seitdem habe ich ehrenamtlich für das Dorf gearbeitet, um etwas von dem zurückzugeben, was mir dort an Großzügigkeit zuteilwurde.

Nun würde ich gerne den nächsten Schritt gehen und eine Hochschulbildung erlangen. Zwei israelische Institutionen haben mich bereits für einen Bachelorstudiengang akzeptiert: Die renommierte Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy and Strategy am Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (IDC) sowie die Tel Aviv-Yafo Academy für den Studiengang Politics and Government. Die Studiengebühren für diese Studiengänge sind sehr hoch, denn das israelische Hochschulsystem wie das amerikanische strukturiert ist. In meinem jetzigen Zustand darf ich Israel nicht verlassen, weil mein Aufenthaltserlaubnis jederzeit ablaufen könnte. Momentan bin ich davor geschützt nur dank des Jugenddorfes. Die Möglichkeit, woanders zu studieren, ist mir daher zurzeit verweigert.

Das Studium ist der Grund, aus dem ich das Flüchtlingscamp im Tschad verlassen habe. Trotz aller Widerstände, die sich mir seitdem in den Weg gestellt haben, habe ich dieses Ziel und diesen Traum nie aus den Augen verloren. 

Ich habe hart gearbeitet, um gute Noten in der Schule zu bekommen, und auch die Zusage zweier israelischer Hochschulinstitutionen ist das Ergebnis harter Arbeit. Mein Ziel ist es, einen Abschluss in Politikwissenschaft und Internationalen Beziehungen zu erhalten. Anschließend möchte ich in mein Land zurückgehen und dabei helfen, ein friedvolles Zusammenleben zu ermöglichen. Außerdem möchte ich Brücken bauen zwischen meinem ersten Zuhause, Afrika, und meinem zweiten Zuhause, Israel – dem Land jener Menschen, von denen ich noch immer annehme, dass sie meine Situation am besten nachvollziehen können, da sie die gleichen Erfahrungen gemacht haben wie ich. 

Während ich diese Ziele verfolge, vergesse ich nicht meine Brüder und Schwestern, die durch die gleiche Hölle gegangen sind wie ich. Wie bisher werde ich daher die Insassen der Internierungslager für Geflüchtete besuchen und Geflüchteten in Israel helfen, die Schwierigkeiten haben. Außerdem werde ich das Jugenddorf nicht vergessen, das mir die Möglichkeit eröffnete, gut zu leben und zu studieren. Daher werde ich auch weiterhin als Freiwilliger für die unterschiedlichen Einrichtungen des Dorfes arbeiten. 

Das Einzige, was mich nun noch von meinem ersten Abschluss trennt, sind die Studiengebühren. 

Ich wäre unendlich dankbar für Ihre Unterstützung. Sie wäre ein wichtiger Beitrag zur Realisierung meines persönlichen Zieles, das gleichsam eine politische Vision ist: Eine Form ziviler Konfliktlösung zu fördern, die einen Konflikt beenden würde, der schon jetzt viel zu viele Leben gekostet hat. 

(Deutscher Text: Max Czollek & Corinne Kaszner)


Mi chiamo Usumain (Ismail) Baraka. Ho bisogno del tuo sostegno per finanziare i miei studi. Il mio sogno è poter studiare politica internazionale, diplomazia e diritto per contribuire alla risoluzione di conflitti e situazioni di crisi. Questa è la mia storia:

Sono nato nel 1994 a Dirhata, un piccolo villaggio nel Darfur, nella parte occidentale del Sudan. Nel 2003, quando le milizie degli Janjaweed sono arrivate al mio villaggio per uccidere tutti gli uomini e i bambini maschi, avevo nove anni. Mio padre e mio fratello maggiore sono stati uccisi a fucilate. Mia mamma mi ha fatto indossare i vestiti delle mie sorelle, facendomi passare per una bambina. Così mi sono salvato. I miliziani l’hanno colpita e colpita, chiedendole dove fossero i suoi altri figli, ma lei ha insistito che le erano rimaste solo bambine. I miliziani ci hanno chiusi nella nostra casa di legno e le hanno dato fuoco, aspettando fuori dalla porta per essere sicuri che nessuno sopravvivesse. Mia mamma ci ha detto di piangere e gridare. In questo modo i miliziani hanno creduto che stessimo morendo e se ne sono andati. Mia mamma ha aperto uno squarcio nel legno, siamo scappati dalla casa in fiamme e abbiamo abbandonato il villaggio alle nostre spalle. Fuggendo per i campi, abbiamo trovato il corpo di mio padre e dopo qualche metro, quello di mio fratello. Siamo arrivati a un campo profughi dell’ONU nel Chad, dove abbiamo vissuto insieme fino al 2007. A quel punto non ce l’ho più fatta a vivere nelle condizioni disumane del campo. Invece di tornare al mio villaggio e combattere, volevo studiare.

Allora ho capito che l’unica speranza di tornare un giorno nel mio paese con i miei cari fosse studiare, sforzarsi di capire la situazione politica e la sua evoluzione, cercare di trovare soluzioni non violente per aiutare a risolvere i conflitti in corso e contribuire a costruire la pace. 

Quando ho lasciato il campo profughi, mettendomi in viaggio da solo e lasciando dietro di me i miei cari, avevo solo tredici anni. 

Ho attraversato il Chad e sono arrivato in Libia. Nella città di Bengasi ho iniziato a studiare l'inglese e a lavorare in una piccola bottega, guadagnandomi così da vivere. Dopo un anno e mezzo mi sono spostato con un amico in Egitto, dove ci avevano detto che avremmo potuto studiare e gli studi non sarebbero stati troppo costosi. Ma il governo egiziano stava collaborando con quello sudanese e rimandava i profughi del Darfur in Sudan, dove ci aspettava o imprigionamento a vita e tortura o la morte. Dovevo lasciare l’Egitto. 

Un giorno ho visto in televisione un documentario sulla Shoah, l’olocausto ebraico. L’unica cosa che sapevo del popolo ebraico era che Israele è l’unico stato ebraico nel mondo. Guardando il documentario, sono venuto a conoscenza per la prima volta della storia degli ebrei, della liberazione dalla schiavitù in Egitto raccontata nella Bibbia, delle persecuzioni e discriminazioni sofferte nei secoli, fino alla fondazione dello stato ebraico, dove gli ebrei possono vivere in libertà. Ho sentito un forte senso di identificazione con la storia del popolo ebraico e non ho avuto dubbi che gli israeliani avrebbero solidarizzato con la mia storia e la storia del mio popolo: ho deciso che dovevo andare in Israele.

Sono entrato in contatto con un trafficante di migranti che faceva la spola fino al confine con Israele. Eravamo dodici persone, tra cui io e il mio amico. Nella notte, ci siamo avvicinati al confine israeliano strisciando e abbiamo cercato di evitare i soldati egiziani con l’aiuto del buio. Improvvisamente, qualcuno nel gruppo ha avuto un attacco di panico, è saltato in piedi e ha iniziato a gridare. Tre pallottole nella testa, sparate dai soldati, lo hanno ucciso sul posto. I soldati hanno quindi iniziato a venire nella nostra direzione. Non avevamo altra scelta che correre verso la recinsione del confine israeliano e sperare che le pallottole non ci colpissero. Abbiamo gettato tutto quello che avevamo con noi e abbiamo corso, corso, corso. Io e il mio amico abbiamo corso veloce quanto potevamo, tenendoci per mano. Un altro uomo del gruppo è stato colpito a morte, e con lui il suo amico che era tornato indietro per aiutarlo. Siamo riusciti a raggiungere la recinsione di filo spinato e a scavalcarla. I soldati israeliani ci sono venuti incontro, ci hanno dato acqua e hanno curato le nostre ferite.

Sono stato portato in una prigione, dove sono rimasto un mese e mezzo nel settore degli adulti. Quando sono stato rilasciato, mi hanno dato un visto temporaneo. Sono andato a Tel Aviv, dove ho vissuto in grande incertezza. Ma anche lì sono riuscito a continuare a studiare inglese. Nel 2010 sono stato accolto a Yemin Orde, un villaggio che ospita giovani migranti e rifugiati, fornendo loro un posto dove vivere e la possibilità di studiare. Mi sono sentito al sicuro per la prima volta da quando sono arrivato in Israele. Ho studiato l’ebraico e fatto il liceo nel villaggio di accoglienza. Nel 2014 ho fatto la maturità. Da allora, faccio volontariato nel villaggio, cercando di dare indietro qualcosa di quello che mi è stato donato così generosamente.

Adesso vorrei poter studiare all’università. Qui in Israele sono stato accettato in due istituzioni accademiche con facoltà a numero chiuso: la prestigiosa “Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy and Strategy at the Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya” e il corso di laurea triennale “Politics and Government at the Tel Aviv-Yafo Academy”. Tutte e due i corsi di studio sono molto costosi, perché il sistema universitario israeliano funziona come quello americano. Nella mia situazione attuale non posso lasciare Israele, in quanto ho solo un visto temporaneo che potrebbe essere revocato in ogni momento se non fosse per la protezione che il villaggio Yemin Orde mi garantisce. Al momento non ho quindi la possibilità di andare a studiare da un’altra parte.

Studiare è il motivo per cui ho lasciato il campo profughi in Chad. Nonostante tutte le difficoltà che ho dovuto affrontare da allora, non ho mai dimenticato il mio sogno. 

Ho studiato duramente per ottenere buoni voti al liceo, e il fatto di essere stato accettato in queste due istituzioni accademiche di alto livello è il frutto di merito, impegno e intenso lavoro. Il mio più grande desiderio è avere la possibilità di studiare e poter ottenere una laurea in scienze politiche e relazioni internazionali. Voglio tornare al mio paese e aiutare la mia gente a vivere in pace nella loro terra. Voglio costruire un ponte tra la mia prima casa, l’Africa, e la mia seconda casa, Israele – il paese del popolo che sono ancora convinto può indentificarsi meglio di chiunque altro con la mia situazione, dal momento che il popolo di Israele ha vissuto esattamente la mia stessa tragica e dolorosa esperienza.

Mentre cerco di realizzare il mio scopo, preparandomi a studiare all’università, non dimentico i miei fratelli e sorelle che hanno dovuto attraversare lo stesso inferno che ho conosciuto anch’io. Come ho fatto fino ad ora, continuo ad aiutare altri rifugiati che vivono in Israele e vanno incontro a mille difficoltà, e continuo a visitare le persone incarcerate nel campi di detenzione per rifugiati. Non dimentico neanche il villaggio d’accoglienza per giovani che mi ha dato la possibilità di vivere serenamente e studiare. Un altro dei miei compiti settimanali è il volontariato nelle strutture del villaggio.

L’unica cosa che mi separa dalla mia laurea triennale non è la voglia, la determinazione e la capacità di studiare e lavorare sodo, ma sono le tasse universitarie estremamente onerose.

Ti sarei infitamente grato – di una gratitudine più profonda di ogni parola – se potessi aiutarmi nell’impresa di raccogliere fondi per i miei studi, così che io possa raggiungere lo scopo che mi sono prefisso, possa laurearmi e aiutare in maniera pacifica a risolvere conflitti che sono costati già troppe vite.
story_txt:
English textHebrew textText auf DeutschTesto in italianoMy name is Usumain (Ismail) Baraka. I need your help in order to finance my undergraduate studies in political science, so that I can pursue my dream of being in the front line to end conflicts in diplomatic ways. This is my story:
I was born in 1994 in Dirhata, a small village in Darfur, in the western part of Sudan. In 2003, when the Janjaweed militias came to kill all the males, I was nine years old. My father and older brother were shot dead. I was saved only because my mother dressed me as a girl. The killers hit her and asked where her other sons were, but she said she only had daughters left: these were my sisters and I. The militias burned the house, waiting outside to make sure we were dead. My mother told us to cry and shout. The militias thus thought we were dying and left the place. We escaped the burning house and left the village. On the way, we spotted my fatherʼs body, and few meters ahead my brotherʼs. We arrived to a UN refugees camp in Chad, in which we lived together until 2007. At that point I decided I could no longer live in the hard conditions of the camp. Rather than going back to our village and fight, I wanted to study. 
I realized we could gain back our homes by studying, by understanding the political situation and how it evolved, and by coming up with non-violent ways to make peace and end the genocide. 
I left the UN camp when I was only thirteen, leaving behind my
beloved ones.



I crossed Chad and reached Libya. In the city of Bengazi I started learning English and I worked in a shop, earning some money for living. After a year and a half I moved with a friend to Egypt, where studying was cheap, according to what I had heard. But the Egyptian and Sudanese governments collaborated to send the Darfur people back, only to face either limitless imprisonment or death. I had to leave Egypt.
One day, on the television, I watched a
documentary about the Shoah, the Jewish Holocaust. The only thing I knew about
the Jews was that Israel is the only Jewish country in the world. Watching the
documentary, I learned about the Jewish people's past, about their being freed
from slavery in Egypt, about the persecutions and discrimination they have suffered
over the centuries until they were able to found their own country and live
there freely. I could identify myself with this story and I had no doubt that
the Jewish people would sympathize with my and my people's story: I had to go
to Israel.



I got in touch with someone who smuggled migrants
over the border to Israel. We were twelve people in the group, including me and
my friend. At night, we crawled towards the Israeli part, trying to avoid the
Egyptian soldiers. Then, suddenly, someone in the group got panicked: he jumped to his feet and started shouting. Three bullets in the head, shot by the
soldiers, killed him on the spot. The soldiers now came in our direction and we
had no choice but to start running towards the Israeli border fence and hope
that the bullets would not hit us. We dropped everything we had and ran, ran
ran. My friend and I ran as fast as we could, holding hands. On the way,
another man in the group was shot dead, followed by his fellow who came back to
assist him. The rest of us reached the border fence and climbed on it. The
Israeli soldiers gave us water and treated our wounds.
I was taken to a prison, where I spent a month and
a half in the adults section. When I was released, I got a temporary visa and moved
to Tel Aviv, where I lived without any clear purpose. But I kept learning
English. In 2010 I moved to Yemin Orde, a youth village that provides migrants and refugees with
a place to live in and with the possibility to study. I felt safe for the first
time since I had arrived to Israel. I learned Hebrew and did high school there.
In 2014, I finished my exams. Since then, I have been volunteering in the
village, trying to give back at least some of what I have received there so
generously.



Now I would like to make the next step and acquire
higher education. I have already been accepted to undergraduate studies in two
Israeli institutions, between which I have to choose: the prestigious Lauder
School of Government, Diplomacy and Strategy at the Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (IDC) and the
first degree in Politics and Government at the Tel Aviv-Yafo Academy.




Studying is the reason I why left the camp in
Chad. Despite all the difficulties I encountered ever since, I have never
forgotten this goal and dream. 
I learned hard to get good grades in high school,
and also the acceptance to the two institutions of higher education is the
fruit of hard work. I want to have a degree in political science and
international relations. I want to go back to my country and help my people
live in peace on their land. I want to build a bridge between my first
homeland, Africa, and my second one, Israel – the country of the people who I am still
convinced can best identify with my situation, since they had precisely the
same unfortunate experience.




While I am pursuing my goals, I am not forgetting
my brothers and sisters who have gone through the same hell like me. As I have
been doing so far, I will keep helping other refugees who live in Israel and
have difficulties, and visiting inmates in detention camps for refugees. I am
also not forgetting the youth village that has given me the possibility to live
well and study. I am continuing to volunteer in the various facilities of the
village. 



The only thing that separates me from a first
degree are the fees. I would be endlessly grateful to have your support, so
that I can accomplish my goal, graduate successfully and contribute in peaceful
ways to end conflicts that have already demanded too many lives.


שמי אוסומעין
(איסמעיל)
בארכה.
אני זקוק
לעזרתך כדי לממן את לימודי התואר הראשון
שלי במדעי המדינה, כדי
שאוכל להגשים את חלומי ולהילחם כדי לסיים
קונפליקטים בדרכים דיפלומטיות.
זה הסיפור
שלי.



נולדתי בשנת
1994 בדירהטה,
כפר קטן במחוז
דארפור שבמערב סודאן. ב-2003,
כאשר מיליציות
הג'נג'אווידים
באו להרוג את כל הגברים והילדים הזכרים,
הייתי בן
תשע. אבי
ואחי הגדול נורו למוות. אני
ניצלתי רק בזכות אמי שהלבישה אותי כמו
ילדה. הרוצחים
הכו אותה ושאלו אותה איפה הבנים האחרים
שלה, אבל
היא אמרה שנותרו לה רק בנות: אלו
היו אחיותיי ואני. אנשי
המיליציה הציתו את הבית באש, וחיכו
בחוץ כדי לוודא שנשרפנו. אמי
אמרה לנו לצעוק חזק ולבכות, ככה
אנשי המיליציה חשבו שעמדנו למות והלכו
משם. הצלחנו
לברוח מהבית הבוער ועזבנו את הכפר.
בדרך מצאנו
את הגופה של אבא שלי, וכמה
מטרים הלאה משם את זאת של אחי.
הגענו למחנה
פליטים של האו"ם
בצ'אד,
שם גרנו ביחד
עד 2007. בנקודה
הזאת החלטתי שלא יכולתי יותר לחיות בתנאים
הקשים של המחנה. במקום
לחזור לכפר שלנו ולהילחם, רציתי
ללמוד.
הבנתי
שנוכל לקבל את הבית שלנו בחזרה גם על ידי
לימודים, על
ידי שנלמד ונבין את המצב הפוליטי ואיך
הוא התפתח, ועל
ידי מציאת דרכים לא אלימות כדי ליצור שלום
ולסיים את הטבח.
עזבתי
את מחנה האו"ם
כשהייתי רק בן 13, והשארתי
מאחוריי את שרידי משפחתי האהובה.


חציתי את
צ'אד
ומשם הגעתי ללוב. בעיר
בנגאזי התחלתי ללמוד אנגלית ועבדתי בחנות
כדי להרוויח כמה פרוטות. אחרי
שנה וחצי עברתי עם חבר למצרים, שם
הלימודים היו אמורים להיות יותר נגישים,
לפי השמועה.
אבל במציאות,
הממשל המצרי
והסודאני שיתפו פעולה כדי להחזיר את פליטי
דארפור לארצם, שם
חיכתה להם תקופת זמן לא ידועה בכלא,
או מוות.
נאלצתי לעזוב
את מצרים.
יום אחד צפיתי
בטלוויזיה בסרט דוקומנטרי על השואה.
הדבר היחיד
שידעתי עד אז על היהודים הוא שמדינת ישראל
היא המדינה היהודית היחידה בעולם.
כשצפיתי
בסרט, התוודעתי
להיסטוריה של העם היהודי, לשחרורם
מהעבדות במצרים, לרדיפות
והאפליות שהם סבלו במהלך המאות,
עד שהם יכלו
להקים לעצמם מדינה משלהם ולחיות בה
בחופשיות. הזדהיתי
עם הסיפור הזה ולא היה לי ספק שהעם היהודי
יזדהה עם הסיפור שלי ושל עמי:
הייתי חייב
ללכת לישראל. 


יצרתי קשר
עם מישהו שהבריח אנשים מעבר לגבול,
לישראל.
היינו 12
אנשים בקבוצה,
כולל אני
והחבר שלי. בלילה,
זחלנו לכיוון
החלק הישראלי, נמנעים
מהחיילים המצריים. פתאום,
מישהו בקבוצה
נתקף פאניקה: הוא
קפץ על רגליו והתחיל לצעוק. שלושה
כדורים בראש, שנורו
על ידי החיילים, הרגו
אותו במקום. החיילים
התחילו עכשיו לבוא לכיווננו, ולא
הייתה לנו ברירה אלא לקום ולהתחיל לרוץ
לכיוון גדר הגבול הישראלי ולקוות שהכדורים
לא יפגעו בנו. זרקנו
את כל מה שהיה לנו ורצנו, רצנו
בכל כוחנו. חברי
ואני רצנו כמה שיותר מהר, מחזיקים
ידיים. בדרך,
אדם אחר
מהקבוצה נורה למוות, ומיד
אחריו עוד אחד שחזר אחורה כדי לעזור לו.
אנחנו שנשארנו
הגענו לגדר וטיפסנו עליה לצד השני.
החיילים
הישראלים נתנו לנו מים וטיפלו בפצעים
שלנו.




נלקחתי לבית
כלא, שם
שהיתי חודש וחצי במדור של המבוגרים.
כשהשתחררתי,
קיבלתי ויזה
זמנית והגעתי לתל אביב, שם
חייתי ללא מטרה ברורה. אבל
המשכתי ללמוד אנגלית. בשנת
2010 עברתי
לימין אורד, כפר
נוער שמעניק למהגרים ופליטים מקום לגור
בו ואפשרות ללמוד. בפעם
הראשונה מאז הגעתי לישראל הרגשתי בטוח.
למדתי עברית
ועשיתי לימודי בית ספר תיכון.
בשנת 2014
סיימתי בהצלחה
את בחינות הבגרות. מאז
אני מתנדב בכפר במטרה לתת חזרה ולו מעט
מכל מה שקיבלתי שם בנדיבות כה גדולה.



עכשיו אני
רוצה לעשות את הצעד הבא ולהתחיל לימודים
גבוהים. התקבלתי
ללימודי תואר ראשון בשני מוסדות ישראלים,
ביניהם אני
צריך לבחור: התוכנית
היוקרתית בבית הספר לאודר לממשל,
דיפלומטיה
ואסטרטגיה במרכז הבין תחומי הרצליה ולימודי תואר
ראשון בפוליטיקה וממשל באקדמית תל אביב-יפו.
הרצון ללמוד
הוא זה שהביא אותי לעזוב את המחנה בצ'אד.
למרות כל
הקשיים מאז, לא
שכחתי את המטרה הזאת – את החלום הזה.
למדתי קשה
כדי לקבל ציונים טובים בתיכון,
וגם הקבלה
לשני המוסדות להשכלה גבוהה היא פרי עבודה
קשה. אני
רוצה לעשות תואר במדעי המדינה ויחסים
בינלאומיים. אני
רוצה לחזור לארץ שלי ולעזור לאנשים שלי
לחיות בשלום על אדמתם. אני
רוצה לבנות גשר בין מולדתי הראשונה,
אפריקה,
ובין מולדתי
השנייה, ישראל
– הארץ בה חי העם שאני עדיין משוכנע שהוא
היחיד שיכול להזדהות עם המצב שלי,
משום שהוא
עבר בדיוק את אותה חוויה קשה.


בזמן שאני
מגשים את מטרותיי, אני
לא שוכח את אחיי ואחיותיי שעברו את אותו
הגיהנום כמוני. כמו
עד עכשיו, אני
אמשיך לעזור לפליטים אחרים שחיים בארץ
ושיש להם קשיים, ולבקר
את אלו שנמצאים בהסגר. אני
גם לא שוכח את כפר הנוער שנתן לי את האפשרות
לחיות טוב וללמוד. אני
ממשיך להתנדב במוסדות השונים שם.


הדבר היחיד
שמפריד ביני ובין התואר הראשון הוא שכר
הלימוד. אני
אהיה אסיר תודה אם תתמכו בי, כדי
שאוכל להגשים את מטרתי: לסיים
בהצלחה את לימודי התואר ולתרום בדרכי
שלום לסיומם של קונפליקטים שכבר תבעו
יותר מדי חיים.



Mein Name ist Usumain (Ismail) Baraka. Ich brauche Ihre Hilfe, damit ich Politikwissenschaften studieren kann. Das Studium bedeutet für mich einen wichtigen Schritt auf meinem Weg, ein Vorreiter ziviler Konfliktlösung zu sein. Im Folgenden meine Geschichte: 

Ich wurde 1994 in Dirhata,
einem kleinen Dorf in Darfur im
West-Sudan, geboren. Als die Dschandschawid-Milizen 2003 in das Dorf kamen, um
alle männlichen Bewohner zu töten, war ich neun Jahre alt. Mein Vater und mein
Bruder wurden getötet. Ich überlebte, weil mich meine Mutter als Mädchen
verkleidete. Die Mörder schlugen sie und fragten, wo ihre anderen Söhne seien,
aber sie antwortete, dass ihr nur noch Töchter geblieben wären: Sie meinte
meine Schwestern und mich. Die Miliz zündete das Haus an und wartete vor der
Tür, um sicher zu gehen, dass wir tot waren. Meine Mutter sagte uns, dass wir
weinen und schreien sollten. So dachte die Miliz, dass wir gerade starben und
verließ ihren Posten. Wir flüchteten aus dem brennenden Haus und verließen das
Dorf. Auf dem Weg entdeckten wir den
Körper meines Vaters, wenige Meter weiter den meines Bruders. Wir
erreichten ein UN-Flüchtlingscamp im Tschad, in dem wir bis 2007 lebten. In
diesem Jahr entschloss ich mich, die miserablen Zustände in dem Camp nicht
länger zu ertragen. Aber anstatt in mein Dorf zurückzukehren und zu kämpfen, wollte
ich studieren. 
Denn ich verstand, dass wir unser Zuhause nur
zurückgewinnen konnten, wenn wir studierten, wenn wir die politische Situation
verstünden und wie es dazu gekommen war. Wenn wir gewaltlose Wege entwickelten,
Frieden zu schließen und den Genozid zu beenden.
Darum verließ ich das
UN-Flüchtlingscamp. Ich war dreizehn Jahre alt, und ließ meine
geliebte  Familie zurück.

Ich durchquerte den Tschad
und erreichte Libyen. In Bengazi begann ich, Englisch zu lernen und in einem
Shop zu arbeiten, um etwas Geld zu verdienen. Nach anderthalb Jahren zog ich
mit einem Freund nach Ägypten, wo es meinen Informationen nach günstig sein sollte
zu studieren. Aber die ägyptische und die sudanesische Regierungen hatten eine
Übereinkunft getroffen, Menschen aus Darfur zurückzuschicken, wo sie anschließend eine unbegrenzte Gefängnishaft oder der Tod erwarteten.
Deshalb musste ich Ägypten verlassen.
Eines Tages sah ich im
Fernsehen eine Dokumentation über die Shoah, den jüdischen Holocaust.
Das Einzige, was ich bis zu diesem Zeitpunkt über Juden wusste, war, dass
Israel das einzige jüdische Land in der Welt ist. Durch die Dokumentation erfuhr
ich zum ersten Mal von der Geschichte der
Juden, der Befreiung aus der
Sklaverei in Ägypten, den anschließenden Jahrtausenden der Verfolgung und Diskriminierung,
bis sie schließlich ihr eigenes Land gründen konnten, um in Freiheit zu leben. Ich konnte mich mit dieser Geschichte identifizieren
und hatte daher keinen Zweifel, dass die Juden meiner Geschichte und der
Geschichte meiner Leute Empathie entgegen bringen würden: Ich musste nach
Israel gehen.

Also nahm ich mit jemandem
Kontakt auf, der Migranten über die Grenze nach Israel schleuste. Wir waren
zwölf Menschen, einschließlich meines Freundes und mir. Eines Nachts krochen
wir in Richtung der israelischen Grenze, immer darauf bedacht, die ägyptischen
Soldaten zu meiden. Plötzlich geriet einer aus unserer Gruppe in Panik: Er
sprang auf und begann zu brüllen. Die drei Kugeln, die ihn in den Kopf trafen,
töteten ihn sofort. Die Soldaten bewegten sich nun in unsere Richtung, so dass wir keine Wahl hatten als in Richtung der
israelischen Grenze loszulaufen und zu hoffen, dass uns die Kugeln nicht
treffen würden. Also ließen wir alles fallen, was wir mit uns genommen
hatten und rannten, rannten, rannten.
Mein Freund und ich liefen so schnell wir konnten, jeder an der Hand des anderen.
Auf dem Weg wurde ein anderer Mann aus unserer Gruppe erschossen, kurz darauf
sein Freund, der umgekehrt war, um ihm beizustehen. Der Rest unserer Gruppe
erreichte den Grenzzaun und kletterte hinüber. Die israelischen Soldaten gaben
uns Wasser und versorgten unsere Wunden. 
Ich wurde in ein Gefängnis
gebracht, wo ich eineinhalb Monate im Erwachsenentrakt verblieb. Mit meiner
Entlassung erhielt ich ein zeitlich begrenztes Visum und zog nach Tel Aviv, wo
ich anschließend ohne eine wirkliche Perspektive lebte. Dort nahm ich meine
Englischstudien wieder auf. 2010 zog ich nach Yemin Orde, ein Jugenddorf, das Migrant*innen und Geflüchtete mit
einer Unterkunft versorgt und ihnen die Möglichkeit bietet zu studieren. Das erste Mal seit meiner Ankunft in Israel
fühlte ich mich sicher. Ich begann, Hebräisch zu lernen und die Schule zu
besuchen. 2014 konnte ich meine Schulausbildung abschließen. Seitdem habe
ich ehrenamtlich für das Dorf gearbeitet, um etwas von dem zurückzugeben, was
mir dort an Großzügigkeit zuteilwurde.

Nun würde ich gerne den
nächsten Schritt gehen und eine Hochschulbildung erlangen. Zwei israelische Institutionen haben mich bereits für
einen Bachelorstudiengang akzeptiert: Die renommierte Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy and Strategy am Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (IDC)
sowie die Tel Aviv-Yafo Academy für den Studiengang Politics and Government. Die
Studiengebühren für diese Studiengänge sind sehr hoch, denn das israelische Hochschulsystem
wie das amerikanische strukturiert ist. In meinem jetzigen Zustand darf ich
Israel nicht verlassen, weil mein Aufenthaltserlaubnis jederzeit ablaufen
könnte. Momentan bin ich davor geschützt nur dank des Jugenddorfes. Die
Möglichkeit, woanders zu studieren, ist mir daher zurzeit verweigert.

Das Studium ist der Grund, aus dem ich das
Flüchtlingscamp im Tschad verlassen habe. Trotz aller Widerstände, die sich mir
seitdem in den Weg gestellt haben, habe ich dieses Ziel und diesen Traum nie
aus den Augen verloren. 
Ich habe hart
gearbeitet, um gute Noten in der Schule zu bekommen, und auch die Zusage zweier
israelischer Hochschulinstitutionen ist das Ergebnis harter Arbeit. Mein Ziel
ist es, einen Abschluss in Politikwissenschaft und Internationalen Beziehungen
zu erhalten. Anschließend möchte ich in mein Land zurückgehen und dabei helfen,
ein friedvolles Zusammenleben zu ermöglichen. Außerdem möchte ich Brücken
bauen zwischen meinem ersten Zuhause, Afrika, und meinem zweiten Zuhause,
Israel – dem Land jener Menschen, von denen ich noch immer annehme, dass
sie meine Situation am besten nachvollziehen können, da sie die gleichen Erfahrungen
gemacht haben wie ich. 

Während ich diese
Ziele verfolge, vergesse ich nicht meine Brüder und Schwestern, die durch die
gleiche Hölle gegangen sind wie ich. Wie bisher werde ich daher die Insassen
der Internierungslager für Geflüchtete besuchen und Geflüchteten in Israel helfen,
die Schwierigkeiten haben. Außerdem werde ich das Jugenddorf nicht vergessen,
das mir die Möglichkeit eröffnete, gut zu leben und zu studieren. Daher werde
ich auch weiterhin als Freiwilliger für die unterschiedlichen Einrichtungen des
Dorfes arbeiten. 

Das Einzige, was
mich nun noch von meinem ersten Abschluss trennt, sind die Studiengebühren. 
Ich
wäre unendlich dankbar für Ihre Unterstützung. Sie wäre ein wichtiger Beitrag zur Realisierung meines persönlichen
Zieles, das gleichsam eine politische Vision ist: Eine Form ziviler
Konfliktlösung zu fördern, die einen Konflikt beenden würde, der schon jetzt
viel zu viele Leben gekostet hat. 
(Deutscher Text: Max
Czollek & Corinne Kaszner)


Mi chiamo Usumain (Ismail) Baraka. Ho
bisogno del tuo sostegno per finanziare i miei studi. Il mio sogno è poter studiare
politica internazionale, diplomazia e diritto per contribuire alla risoluzione
di conflitti e situazioni di crisi. Questa è la mia storia:

Sono nato nel 1994 a Dirhata, un piccolo
villaggio nel Darfur, nella parte occidentale del Sudan. Nel 2003,
quando le milizie degli Janjaweed sono arrivate al mio villaggio per uccidere
tutti gli uomini e i bambini maschi, avevo nove anni. Mio padre e mio fratello maggiore
sono stati uccisi a fucilate. Mia mamma mi ha fatto indossare i vestiti delle
mie sorelle, facendomi passare per una bambina. Così mi sono salvato. I
miliziani l’hanno colpita e colpita, chiedendole dove fossero i suoi altri
figli, ma lei ha insistito che le erano rimaste solo bambine. I miliziani ci
hanno chiusi nella nostra casa di legno e le hanno dato fuoco, aspettando fuori
dalla porta per essere sicuri che nessuno sopravvivesse. Mia mamma ci ha detto
di piangere e gridare. In questo modo i miliziani hanno creduto che stessimo
morendo e se ne sono andati. Mia mamma ha aperto uno squarcio nel legno, siamo
scappati dalla casa in fiamme e abbiamo abbandonato il villaggio alle nostre
spalle. Fuggendo per i campi, abbiamo trovato il corpo di mio padre e dopo
qualche metro, quello di mio fratello. Siamo arrivati a un campo profughi
dell’ONU nel Chad, dove abbiamo vissuto insieme fino al 2007. A quel punto non
ce l’ho più fatta a vivere nelle condizioni disumane del campo. Invece di
tornare al mio villaggio e combattere, volevo studiare.

Allora ho capito che l’unica speranza di tornare
un giorno nel mio paese con i miei cari fosse studiare, sforzarsi di capire la
situazione politica e la sua evoluzione, cercare di trovare soluzioni non
violente per aiutare a risolvere i conflitti in corso e contribuire a costruire
la pace. 
Quando ho lasciato il campo profughi,
mettendomi in viaggio da solo e lasciando dietro di me i miei cari, avevo solo tredici anni. 

Ho attraversato il Chad e sono arrivato in
Libia. Nella città di Bengasi ho iniziato a studiare l'inglese e a lavorare in
una piccola bottega, guadagnandomi così da vivere. Dopo un anno e mezzo mi sono
spostato con un amico in Egitto, dove ci avevano detto che avremmo potuto
studiare e gli studi non sarebbero stati troppo costosi. Ma il governo egiziano
stava collaborando con quello sudanese e rimandava i profughi del Darfur in Sudan, dove ci aspettava o imprigionamento a vita e tortura o la
morte. Dovevo lasciare l’Egitto. 
Un giorno ho visto in televisione un documentario
sulla Shoah, l’olocausto
ebraico. L’unica cosa che sapevo del popolo ebraico era che Israele è l’unico
stato ebraico nel mondo. Guardando il documentario, sono venuto a conoscenza
per la prima volta della storia degli ebrei, della liberazione dalla
schiavitù in Egitto raccontata nella Bibbia, delle persecuzioni e
discriminazioni sofferte nei secoli, fino alla fondazione dello stato ebraico,
dove gli ebrei possono vivere in libertà. Ho sentito un forte senso di
identificazione con la storia del popolo ebraico e non ho avuto dubbi che gli
israeliani avrebbero solidarizzato con la mia storia e la storia del mio
popolo: ho deciso che dovevo andare in Israele.

Sono entrato in contatto con un trafficante di migranti che
faceva la spola fino al confine con Israele. Eravamo dodici persone, tra cui io
e il mio amico. Nella notte, ci siamo avvicinati al confine israeliano
strisciando e abbiamo cercato di evitare i soldati egiziani con l’aiuto del
buio. Improvvisamente, qualcuno nel gruppo ha avuto un attacco di panico, è
saltato in piedi e ha iniziato a gridare. Tre pallottole nella testa, sparate
dai soldati, lo hanno ucciso sul posto. I soldati hanno quindi iniziato a
venire nella nostra direzione. Non avevamo altra scelta che correre verso la
recinsione del confine israeliano e sperare che le pallottole non ci colpissero.
Abbiamo gettato tutto quello che avevamo con noi e abbiamo corso, corso,
corso. Io e il mio amico abbiamo corso veloce quanto potevamo, tenendoci per
mano. Un altro uomo del gruppo è stato colpito a morte, e con lui il suo
amico che era tornato indietro per aiutarlo. Siamo riusciti a raggiungere la
recinsione di filo spinato e a scavalcarla. I soldati israeliani ci sono venuti
incontro, ci hanno dato acqua e hanno curato le nostre ferite.
Sono stato portato in una prigione, dove sono rimasto un
mese e mezzo nel settore degli adulti. Quando sono stato rilasciato, mi hanno
dato un visto temporaneo. Sono andato a Tel Aviv, dove ho vissuto in grande
incertezza. Ma anche lì sono riuscito a continuare a studiare inglese. Nel 2010
sono stato accolto a Yemin Orde, un villaggio che ospita giovani migranti e
rifugiati, fornendo loro un posto dove vivere e la possibilità di studiare.
Mi sono sentito al sicuro per la prima volta da quando sono arrivato in
Israele. Ho studiato l’ebraico e fatto il liceo nel villaggio di accoglienza.
Nel 2014 ho fatto la maturità. Da allora, faccio volontariato nel
villaggio, cercando di dare indietro qualcosa di quello che mi è stato donato
così generosamente.
Adesso vorrei poter studiare all’università.
Qui in Israele sono stato accettato in due istituzioni accademiche con facoltà a
numero chiuso: la prestigiosa “Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy and Strategy at the Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya” e il corso di laurea triennale
“Politics and Government at the Tel Aviv-Yafo Academy”. Tutte e due i corsi di studio sono molto costosi,
perché il sistema universitario israeliano funziona come quello americano.
Nella mia situazione attuale non posso lasciare Israele, in quanto ho solo un
visto temporaneo che potrebbe essere revocato in ogni momento se non fosse per
la protezione che il villaggio Yemin Orde mi garantisce. Al momento non ho
quindi la possibilità di andare a studiare da un’altra parte.
Studiare è il motivo per cui ho lasciato il
campo profughi in Chad. Nonostante tutte le difficoltà che ho dovuto affrontare
da allora, non ho mai dimenticato il mio sogno. 
Ho studiato duramente per ottenere buoni
voti al liceo, e il fatto di essere stato accettato in queste due istituzioni
accademiche di alto livello è il frutto di merito, impegno e intenso lavoro. Il
mio più grande desiderio è avere la possibilità di studiare e poter ottenere
una laurea in scienze politiche e relazioni internazionali. Voglio tornare al
mio paese e aiutare la mia gente a vivere in pace nella loro terra. Voglio
costruire un ponte tra la mia prima casa, l’Africa, e la mia seconda casa,
Israele – il paese del popolo che sono ancora convinto può indentificarsi
meglio di chiunque altro con la mia situazione, dal momento che il popolo di
Israele ha vissuto esattamente la mia stessa tragica e dolorosa esperienza.

Mentre cerco di realizzare il mio scopo, preparandomi a
studiare all’università, non dimentico i miei fratelli e sorelle che hanno
dovuto attraversare lo stesso inferno che ho conosciuto anch’io. Come ho fatto
fino ad ora, continuo ad aiutare altri rifugiati che vivono in Israele e vanno
incontro a mille difficoltà, e continuo a visitare le persone incarcerate nel
campi di detenzione per rifugiati. Non dimentico neanche il villaggio
d’accoglienza per giovani che mi ha dato la possibilità di vivere serenamente e
studiare. Un altro dei miei compiti settimanali è il volontariato nelle
strutture del villaggio.

L’unica cosa che mi separa dalla mia laurea triennale non
è la voglia, la determinazione e la capacità di studiare e lavorare sodo, ma
sono le tasse universitarie estremamente onerose. 
Ti sarei infitamente grato – di una gratitudine più
profonda di ogni parola – se potessi aiutarmi nell’impresa di raccogliere fondi
per i miei studi, così che io possa raggiungere lo scopo che mi sono prefisso,
possa laurearmi e aiutare in maniera pacifica a risolvere conflitti che sono costati già troppe vite.

story:
Camp Thunderbird South Dakota’s aim is to implement fun, targeted programming that provides participants a chance to practice academic skills during the summer.  We work with incredible youth on the Pine Ridge, Rosebud, Lower Brule, and Standing Rock reservations across South Dakota (Learn more about where we work: http://campthunderbirdsd.org/where-we-work/). These places comprise of some of the poorest counties in the United States with youth suicide rates that are ten times the national average, yet we have seen that students can do amazing things when they are given the chance to explore and lead.

Camp Thunderbird offers a structured, safe place to take risks, learn, build life skills, and realize personal strengths, offsetting the limited opportunities available in these remote and rural areas during the summer.  Frustratingly, students’ here face an academic achievement gap of two to three grade levels. Camp Thunderbird fosters concrete goal-setting skills and self-affirmation, which has been shown to have positive, lasting effects on academic achievement, especially for children most at risk (Cohen et al. 2010 SCIENCE).

Founded and operated by current and previous educators with personal relationships to our students, Camp Thunderbird combines community service; outdoor, cultural, and art education; team building; resiliency; and a brief college stay; all structured to inspire campers to set ambitious long-term goals and to concretely link skills learned at camp to their lives.

Since 2008 we have conducted seven camps. In response to community demand, we expanded from offering just one week-long camp for third through fifth graders, to providing a second camp for middle-school children. In doing so, we more than doubled our participation from 20 to 43 campers and provided continuity for previous campers who would have "aged out." 2015 was also special in that we hired four local high school students, to their first job ever, as junior counselors! We did this thanks to several individual donations, grassroots fundraising events, and grants. We need your help to do it again! (See pictures from previous camps: http://campthunderbirdsd.org/galleries/)

We have a great bunch of volunteers that develop programming, take care of administration needs (http://campthunderbirdsd.org/meet-the-board/), and work on fundraising throughout the year. More than 95% of our budget is devoted to camp -- lodging, stipends for volunteer directors and counselors, junior counselors activities, and transportation. The distances in South Dakota are long, so transportation is one of our greatest expenses. 

Cost of renting two 15-passenger vans for 2 weeks plus insurance: $6,490.00 (we'll need two for all campers and staff)

Cost of renting a staff van for two weeks plus insurance: $800. 

Current gas prices in SD are approximately: $2.00 per gallon

Gas mileage for a 15 passenger van: 11-17 mpg

Estimated fuel costs for two weeks of camp (including staff training, prep, and clean up days): $2,800.00

Approximate distances that are traveled during camp (one trip, one-way, we need to make these trips multiple times):

Between the Rosebud and Pine Ridge Reservations (105 miles one-way) to contact and meet with families and pick up and drop off campers before and after camp.

Between Rosebud Reservation and Rapid City to pick up rental vans, camping and educational supplies, overnight visit to the South Dakota School of Mines (180 miles one way, 75 miles from Badlands to Rapid City)

Between Rosebud and the Badlands and Wall, SD to hike and visit Lakota Ways cultural & educational center (95-120 miles one way)

Between Rosebud and Niabrara Wildlife Refuge near Valentine Nebraska (45 miles one way)

Between Rosebud and Mission, SD or Valentine, NE for groceries and other supplies (13-45 miles one way)

Between the South Dakota Black Hills State University in Spearfish and the entrance to Custer State Park where we hike, camp, and rock climb (75.1 miles one way)

To provide our campers with the great experiences South Dakota have to offer, we must drive. We need your help to do that.

Thank you so much for considering our campaign!

Wopila Tanka

story:
Ken jij iemand die je graag gelukkiger ziet?

Wil jij zelf meer geluk ervaren?

Of ben of ken je iemand die op zoek is naar een nieuwe koers in zijn werk of leven?

Voor mensen op zoek zijn naar een passende koers heb ik een cursus ontwikkeld. Een 12-weekse online cursus ‘Wie ben ik? Wat wil ik’. Daarmee vind je:
- een nieuwe passende koers
- meer dagelijkse geluksmomenten
- meer authenticiteit

Deze cursus heb ik ontwikkeld omdat ik geloof dat als mensen doen wat bij ze past, en met hart en ziel leven en werken, ze maximaal bijdragen aan de wereld.
Het is mijn missie om in 2015 zo’n 1000 hoogopgeleide 50-plussers, te helpen doen wat bij ze past en gelukkiger te worden. Ik heb ruim een jaar aan deze cursus gewerkt en nu heb ik hulp nodig om degenen voor wie het bedoeld is van deze cursus te kunnen laten profiteren.

Waarom zou je mij geloven?
Ik ben hiertoe gekomen omdat ik 25 jaar geleden zelf op een plek zat waar ik niet paste. Daar had ik het gevoel dat ik mijn ziel verkocht had. De ervaringen van mijn ontwikkelingsweg van 10 jaar boeddhisme, 10 jaar kunstenaar en 10 jaar hypnotherapeut bracht ik samen in deze cursus.
Atelier voor LevensKunst richtte ik op in 2001. Van daaruit begeleidde ik honderden mensen op hun weg van bewustwording, leven vanuit hart en ziel, en doen wat bij ze past.

In 2015 wil ik 1000 mensen begeleiden gelukkiger te worden en/of hun nieuwe koers te helpen vinden. Daarvoor heb ik jouw hulp nodig!

Natuurlijk krijg je daar ook wat voor terug:

Een online-pakket waarmee je zelf gelukkiger wordt en/of je iemand anders helpt gelukkiger te worden.
Als je me steunt met € 10 doe je jezelf èn 3 dierbaren of vrienden het 'Creëer Geluk' pakket cadeau. 
Als je me steunt met € 500 neem ik je mee op een inspirerend verdiepingsweekend op het heerlijke eiland Schiermonnikoog, waar we luisteren naar de zee en de wind en ik je op diverse manieren begeleid om een stap verder te komen.
Kijk hiernaast voor de details en alle andere mogelijkheden!  

De opbrengst van deze campagne gebruik ik om de promotie van de cursus financieren.
Bijv om advertenties te plaatsen op banensites en papieren media, om zo nog meer mensen te bereiken.

Bij meer inkomsten, meer geluk!
Daarnaast betekent jouw bijdrage dat ik direct al mensen bereik: jij en degen aan wie je je tegenprestatie weggeeft.
Bij 150 bijdragen van € 10 plus
100 van € 25 plus
100 van € 57 heb ik 1000 mensen bereikt!

Wil je eerst weten wat je weggeeft?
Voor € 5 stuur ik het 'Creëer Geluk' -pakket naar je toe zodat je het eerst zelf kunt ervaren. Daarna kun je het aan iemand weggeven of € 5 extra doneren om het 'Creëer Geluk' pakket  aan 3 van je dierbaren of vrienden cadeau te doen.

Ander bedrag?
Voor ieder veelvoud van deze bedragen, geef ik je graag het bijbehorende aantal tegenprestaties. Mocht je niks terug willen ontvangen voor je donatie, wil je dat laten weten? Dan geef ik jouw tegenprestatie weg aan iemand anders.

Kleinere contributie later upgraden?
Heb je eerst een kleinere bijdrage gedaan, bijv de Passietest en wil je later upgraden naar de hele cursus 'Wie ben ik? Wat wil ik?'? Kies dan opnieuw voor je oorspronkelijke tegenprestatie (in dit voorbeeld de Passietest) en voeg in het vervolgscherm het prijsverschil (hier € 132) toe mbv 'custom'. Ik weet dan automatisch dat ik je de hele cursus kan toesturen. Dit geldt ook voor upgrade van de andere bijdragen.

Hoe gaat weggeven in zijn werk?
Na je investering ontvang je van mij een mail met een bevestigingslink om zelf de tegenprestatie te ontvangen. Daarin bied ik je 2 mogelijkheden:
1. Je stuurt mij de mailadressen van degenen aan wie je het weggeeft. Ik stuur hen dan namens jou een mail dat jij ze een Cadeau hebt gegeven. Ze krijgen dan een bevestigingslink of de link naar de inschrijvingspagina (afhankelijk van het product)
2. Jij laat zelf je vrienden weten dat je een cadeau voor ze hebt. Daarvoor stuur ik je een conceptmail met gegevens en informatie.

Investeer ook in Geluk door deze campagne te delen op facebook, twitter, linked in of in via je mail bestand. Gebruik daarvoor de deelknoppen op deze pagina.

Weet je 1 of 2 personen in je netwerk aan wie je dit gericht wilt doorsturen?
Ook daar ben ik heel blij mee!
Investering 
Via deze website betaal je met Paypal. Heb je geen PayPal account? Maak er eenvoudig één aan om via deze site te betalen. Zie ook http://www.hoedoe.nl/computers/internet/website.... Daar help je mij mee omdat je bijdrage dan rechtstreeks hier zichtbaar wordt, en dat stimuleert anderen.
Wil je dat niet? Investeer dan via NL53 TRIO 0254 8514 52 tnv Atelier voor LevensKunst. Zet dan ook je mailadres in je overboeking, zodat ik weet waar ik mijn tegenprestatie heen kan sturen. Mail me ook dat je de overboeking hebt gedaan, dan kan ik je bijdrage direct bij de resultaten op deze Investeer in Geluk! - webpagina toevoegen. Zeker tegen het einde van de campagne is dat van belang, omdat ik dan weet of ik mijn doel bereik!
Laat je vooral niet weerhouden door deze eventuele tussenstap.
Ik heb je steun echt nodig! Dankjewel.

een Betere Wereld begint bij Individuele Bezieling
story_txt:
Ken jij iemand die je graag gelukkiger ziet?
Wil jij zelf meer geluk ervaren? 
Of ben of ken je iemand die op zoek is naar een nieuwe koers in zijn werk of leven?
Voor mensen op zoek zijn naar een passende koers heb ik een cursus ontwikkeld. Een 12-weekse online
cursus ‘Wie ben ik? Wat wil ik’. Daarmee vind je:- een nieuwe passende koers- meer dagelijkse geluksmomenten- meer authenticiteit 
Deze cursus heb ik ontwikkeld omdat ik geloof dat als mensen doen wat bij ze past, en met hart
en ziel leven en werken, ze maximaal bijdragen aan de wereld.Het is mijn missie om in 2015
zo’n 1000 hoogopgeleide 50-plussers, te helpen doen wat bij ze past en
gelukkiger te worden. Ik heb ruim een jaar aan deze cursus gewerkt en nu heb ik hulp nodig om degenen voor wie het bedoeld is van deze cursus te kunnen laten profiteren.
Waarom zou je mij geloven? Ik ben hiertoe gekomen omdat ik 25 jaar geleden zelf op een plek zat waar ik niet paste. Daar had ik het gevoel dat ik mijn ziel verkocht had. De ervaringen van mijn ontwikkelingsweg van 10 jaar boeddhisme, 10 jaar kunstenaar en 10 jaar hypnotherapeut bracht ik samen in deze cursus. Atelier voor LevensKunst richtte ik op in 2001. Van daaruit begeleidde ik honderden mensen op hun weg van bewustwording, leven vanuit hart en ziel, en doen wat bij ze past. 
In 2015 wil ik 1000 mensen begeleiden gelukkiger te worden en/of hun nieuwe koers te helpen vinden. Daarvoor heb ik jouw hulp nodig! 
Natuurlijk krijg je daar ook wat voor terug:Een online-pakket waarmee je zelf gelukkiger wordt en/of je iemand anders helpt gelukkiger te worden. Als je me steunt met € 10 doe je jezelf èn 3 dierbaren of vrienden het 'Creëer Geluk' pakket 
cadeau.  Als je me steunt met € 500 neem ik je mee op een inspirerend verdiepingsweekend op het heerlijke eiland Schiermonnikoog, waar we luisteren naar de zee en de wind en ik je op diverse manieren begeleid om een stap verder te komen.Kijk hiernaast voor de details en alle andere mogelijkheden!   
De opbrengst van deze campagne gebruik ik om de promotie van de cursus financieren. Bijv om advertenties te plaatsen op banensites en papieren media, om zo nog meer mensen te bereiken. 
Bij meer inkomsten, meer geluk!Daarnaast betekent jouw bijdrage dat ik direct al mensen bereik: jij en degen aan wie je je tegenprestatie weggeeft.Bij 150 bijdragen van € 10 plus100 van € 25 plus100 van € 57 heb ik 1000 mensen bereikt!
Wil je eerst weten wat je weggeeft?Voor € 5 stuur ik het 'Creëer Geluk' -pakket naar je toe zodat je het 
eerst zelf kunt ervaren. Daarna kun je het aan iemand weggeven of € 5 extra 
doneren om het 'Creëer Geluk' pakket  aan 3 van je dierbaren of vrienden
cadeau te doen. 
Ander bedrag? Voor ieder veelvoud van deze bedragen, geef ik je graag het bijbehorende aantal tegenprestaties. Mocht je niks terug willen ontvangen voor je donatie, wil je dat laten weten? Dan geef ik jouw tegenprestatie weg aan iemand anders. 
Kleinere contributie later upgraden?Heb je eerst een kleinere bijdrage gedaan, bijv de Passietest en wil je later upgraden naar de hele cursus 'Wie ben ik? Wat wil ik?'? Kies dan opnieuw voor je oorspronkelijke tegenprestatie (in dit voorbeeld de Passietest) en voeg in het vervolgscherm het prijsverschil (hier € 132) toe mbv 'custom'. Ik weet dan automatisch dat ik je de hele cursus kan toesturen. Dit geldt ook voor upgrade van de andere bijdragen.
Hoe gaat weggeven in zijn werk?Na je investering ontvang je van mij een mail met een bevestigingslink om zelf de tegenprestatie te ontvangen. Daarin bied ik je 2 mogelijkheden:1. Je stuurt mij de mailadressen van degenen aan wie je het weggeeft. Ik stuur hen dan namens jou een mail dat jij ze een Cadeau hebt gegeven. Ze krijgen dan een bevestigingslink of de link naar de inschrijvingspagina (afhankelijk van het product)2. Jij laat zelf je vrienden weten dat je een cadeau voor ze hebt. Daarvoor stuur ik je een conceptmail met gegevens en informatie.
Investeer ook in Geluk door deze campagne te delen op facebook, twitter, linked in of in via je mail bestand. Gebruik daarvoor de deelknoppen op deze pagina.Weet je 1 of 2 personen in je netwerk aan wie je dit gericht wilt doorsturen?Ook daar ben ik heel blij mee!

voor LevensKunst. Zet dan ook je mailadres in je overboeking, zodat ik weet waar ik mijn tegenprestatie heen kan sturen. story:
Short Summary

Dear valued donators,

My name is Jeff Picca. I have been a NYC public school teacher for 13 years and a Model U.N. coordinator for 12. Over that time I have used this program to help bright young inner city scholars to broaden their horizons and truly become global citizens. This program exposes them to geopolitical problem solving, helps develop their public speaking skills as well as gain confidence in their abilities as students.

Your generous donations will allow students to attend conferences at the University of Virginia, Harvard and the George Washington University. These conferences also allow our students to get a feel for highly competitive academics that cannot be replicated in an overcrowded inner city class room. 


    What We Need & What You Get


    • We are hoping to raise $12,000.00 to in order to attend the 3 conferences this year.
    • We need to cover the costs of transportation and boarding for students whose parents do not have the funds to have their sons/daughters participate.
    • Any donation will receive a personal letter from one of the students you helped send to a conference. 
    • All funds will be used to cover the above mentioned expenses. It averages around $300 per student per conference. We have over 45 students and hope to divide the funds so that each student can attend 1 conference. Any unused funds would go into the school account and be set aside for next school year.

    The Impact

    Participating in Model U.N.

    • builds global citizenship
    • helps to develop problem solving skills
    • develops public speaking skills
    • opens doors by building their college resume 
    • exposes students to a highly competitive academic atmosphere

      Risks & Challenges

      If we do not get funding we simply cannot attend. I as the coordinator take no salary or stipend to do this. I try to keep the club going because I believe in what it does for students. I will always work to ensure that the economically disadvantaged get to show the world their talents. In the past I have even dug into my own pocket if it meant that a student could attend rather than be left out of an enriching experience.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you cannot donate, we still appreciate any networking of our fund raiser that you are willing to do. What more worthy cause than the education of the next generation.

story:
Let's build a classroom in Malawi... Let's go!

Most children in Malawi learn under a tree. It becomes increasingly difficult during the rainy season. Today, you can help Urunji Child-Care Trust change that by donating $20 or more towards a classroom block construction. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are happy to tell you that the community has already contributed bricks towards this project. This cuts our budget by 35%. We only need $20,000 to cover the rest.

There's a perk for you: If you donate $100 or more, we will surely send you a hand-made card from a child. When you donate $500 or more, we will send you African cloth material (commonly called 'Chitenje')as a gift. 

Yes, if you donate $1,000 or more, we will send you a unique African print material, a card and a bracelet pack.

When you donate the whole $20,000 we will put a placard on the classroom block detailing your contribution and name. You will also get all the perks such as African material, a card, you name it!

The Impact, Result and the Change

You love to make a difference and we love to put our hands to work. Your support will enable 200 children to learn under a shelter this rainy season. We are already providing free meals at this school and the enrollment has improved.

Risks & Challenges

Basically none... but we don't take things for granted.  Neither do you! So with your support, we will engage a reputable contractor to build this structure so that it meets and exceed the required standards where possible.

All funds received by Urunji Child-Care Trust are externally audited by a reputable firm and the audit report is available to all our partners and stakeholders upon request. All the donations received on this platform will be wired to the official Urunji Child-Care Trust bank account and put to this project immediately.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to donate now? There's still something you can do! Meanwhile you can support us by sharing this campaign with your friends and family, liking our Facebook page and tweeting about this campaign. You can also help us get support from corporate donors. Contact us for more information on how to get involved.

story:
The Poetry Game has been printed, look beautiful. You can still order here!

Poetry Game Overview

The Poetry Game makes a perfect gift and an interactive game for ages 10-adult. It's a beautifully designed deck of cards, complete with instructions, and a lovely box. Our basic game is played in English. We now have Arabic, Yiddish, and Spanish versions. You don't need to know the language to play -- you learn as you go. The game can be played at home, with faith communities, in classes, and where ever you want to have fun and be creative with friends. 

The game makes it easy and enjoyable to write poems, no matter your level of experience -- from "never wrote a poem before" to published poet. It builds community as well-- play and break the ice with people you don’t know or get to know friends and family on a deeper level.

Update:  The initial campaign enabled us to design and print our cards. We have versions in English, Yiddish and Arabic, and a new Spanish version, You can still use this campaign to buy decks of Poetry Game cards. or to make a donation. Donations help us offer workshops in schools, senior centers, and faith communities. 

The Poetry Game  promotes the preservation of culture and language. When you play the Spanish, Yiddish or Arabic versions of the game, you learn new words and cultural concepts, and integrate these words and ideas into poems. No prior knowledge of either language is needed to play, but it can also be used by fluent speakers or language learners.

It’s a perfect gift for:

* Word game lovers

*Language-learners

* Educators 

* Students of poetry or literature

* Trainers or facilitators looking for icebreaker games

*Anyone with an interest in writing

The Poetry Game Project is a nonprofit organization that offers Poetry Game workshops for schools, faith communities, seniors, and others.

Where will your money go?

When you buy a deck of cards, your funds pay for the printing costs (on paper certified forest sustainable) and delivery.  Funds also make it possible for our team to facilitate poetry workshops in the D.C. community (at schools, after-school programs, religious and senior centers). And 10% of profits will support our partner poetry organization, Split This Rock.

Our Story

The roots for the Poetry Game began spontaneously at a dinner party that was hosted by Zahara Heckscher. Zahara's students at the University of Maryland, College Park decided to turn the game into a physical deck of cards. Since then, the game has been revised to feature a sleeker design and updated instruction cards! Zahara and her team have workshopped the new version of The Poetry Game in community centers and schools around D.C. and have been met with high levels of interest and enthusiasm. 

"The game teaches people regardless of their age or gender, that there are no limits to your creativity and imagination" -
Iona Senior Center Participant

“I wouldn’t change anything about The Poetry Game, it was awesome”
- Student at Stuart-Hobson Middle School summer program

“My goal going into the Poetry Game was to introduce the students to new Arabic words, and that goal was definitely met"
- Teacher at University of Maryland

“Students were extremely engaged and participated fully -- even a student who I know to be very withdrawn"
- Teacher from Burrville Elementary School

What The Game Contains

  • Dozens of prompt cards

  • Instructions on how to play -- the game is non-competitive and everyone wins

  • Card box with a lovely design

The English Poetry Game features a bold purple white black design, suitable for all ages (10 and up) and genders.

The Yiddish Poetry Game helps you learn Yiddish words as you play, some well known, and some unusual words.

How to Play?

The game begins with three prompt cards being dealt to every player. The prompts include guidelines such as:

  • Include an animal sound
  • Give voice to an inanimate object
  • Include a reference to a body of water

Each player then selects one of the three cards to put into the middle. A timer starts and each person writes a poem including as many prompts from the middle as possible (3 or more is usually what's recommended). After time is up, those who want to share their poems. However, the focus of the game is appreciation, not critique or judgement. You can play unlimited rounds with new prompts every time!

Meet the Team

Zahara Heckscher (Founder)

Zahara is a writer, educator and social justice advocate. As a breast cancer "thriver," she frequently advocates for cancer medication accessibility. She specializes in International Volunteering and has written a guide entitled: How to Live Your Dream of Volunteering Overseas (Penguin 2002). She is currently writing a follow-up book entitled Learning Service: The Essential Guide to International Volunteer Travel. She has taught and lectured at colleges around the country on her experiences with international volunteering dos and don'ts.   

The Poetry Game is a fiscally sponsored project of the Washington Peace Center.

Advisory Board

Yael Flusberg (Integrative Yoga Therapist and Coach)

Bracha Laster, Ed.D (Professor, Towson University, Maryland)

Amy Markowitz (Educator)

E. Ethelbert Miller (Writer and and Literary Activist)

Yvette Neisser (Poet)

Josephine “Jo” Reed (Radio Journalist)

Heba Salem (Senior Arabic Language Instructor)

Johnna Schmidt (Director, Jiménez-Porter Writers’ House, University of Maryland, College Park)

The Impact

The game strives to bridge gaps between people of varying ages, backgrounds, life experiences and ability levels. We help promote self-expression, literacy, writing skills development and above all, connection. Our workshops often take on a unifying and community building role for participants. We have built a network of strong relationships with school systems and community centers including Iona Senior Services, Hearst Elementary School, The Jewish Study Center, and we will continue to do so in the future with your help. 

Ways You Can Support Us

  • Do your gift shopping at this page
  • Buy a perk or make a donation
  • Spread the word to friends and family. Encourage them to purchase their own copy of the game or donate to our cause.
  • Share! Help us increase our campaign's scope and visibility.
  • Follow us on social media https://www.facebook.com/thepoetrygameproject/
  • Send us your feedback! We want to know what YOU think (Zaharapeace@gmail.com.)

Do your gift shopping at this page
Buy a perk or make a donation

Spread the word to friends and family. Encourage them to purchase their own copy of the game or donate to our cause.

Send us your feedback! We want to know what YOU think (Zaharapeace@gmail.com.)

story:
I hope this campaign will offer some help to at least 100 hundred family of those who lost their homes and their loved ones, i wish i could be a good connection between you and them as they really need your help, their situations is just awful.

help us so we can help them, please donate and share.

story:
Hello.

My name is Victoria Velazquez and I am applying for admittance into New York University - Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music (NYU).  As part of the application process, I am required to submit a Creative Sample Video to demonstrate my talents.  I have to show the Admissions Committee that I have want it takes to be successful at NYU. 

Many of you may know that I'm a singer/songwriter and a member of AVE'  (aka The Velazquez Family Singers) - 3 x Stellar Awards Nominees and 2 x winners of McDonald's Gospelfest.  However, over the past few years, I’ve development interests and skills in the area of Music Executive Entrepreneurship.   In other words, I want to be the “person-in-charge” behind the scenes. 


THIS IS WHERE I HOPE YOU WILL HELP.

I've decided to film my experience of executive producing a record from beginning to end.  My process begins with coming up with a great idea and funding it (that’s why I here today).  I will sing, arrange, produce, and executive produce a song I wrote.  However, instead of asking for your donations, I want to offer you ownership shares in my project.  This fundraising will not only  help me pay for this project, it will really emphasizes the entrepreneurship aspect of my NYU application.  I will retain 50% ownership on this song and sell 50% (or $1,000) to the general public.  I plan to give a 1.25% interest of the song to those who contribute every $25 (1 share) to my project.  That means for a $100 contribution, you will retain a 5% interest in my song which means you will receive 5% of the net income generated from the song.  Now I doubt that this project will make enough money to pay off your mortgage, but who knows - you may be able to cover your original investment in my project; plus take your sweetheart to the movies. 

I need to raise money within a few weeks, so please consider contributing today.  I really want to go to NYU and you are a real significant factor in achieving my goals in higher learning.  If you can't contribute $25 or don't want ownership in my record, please contribute what you can. Thank you for your time and consideration.

May GOD continue to Bless,
Victoria Velazquez

story:
"I was a rather sheltered 19 year old at the time, and I would never have gotten the opportunity to go if it wasn't for your campaign to raise money for tickets." Kay

QEDcon is a science and skepticism convention that takes place in Manchester, England. Over three days a whole range of events allow attendees to learn new rational thinking skills, hear world-class speakers, meet like-minded people and be challenged. 
photo by Rob 

QEDcon is a top quality outreach event that I raise money every year to buy tickets for people to attend who otherwise would not have been able to afford to go. The social aspect of the convention also brings together like-minded people which is invaluable. 

"I am now training to become a teacher. Without the opportunity to attend QED, I doubt I would have decided to undertake this change in career path." Andy

Make a donation today and help me send ten people to QEDcon in October. You never know what it might inspire! If I beat the target I'll buy more tickets for more people. 

"I got to meet Richard Dawkins and Lawrence Krauss whose writing helped me through a traumatic breakaway from my religious family. I was able to thank them in person for their inspiration and I'll remember that for the rest of my life" Anon
