story:
For the last five years we have been running this initiative to impact hundreds of young people, girls and women in taking the step to follow their personal goals, passions and dreams, to be creative and innovative as young entrepreneur’s in helping solve community problems through their entrepreneurial mindset and spirit which at the end moves them from poverty to job creator and from dependency to independent.

After five year, the call from more young people to join over program has increased in numbers. Hopin Academy is the only initiative working with the youth in entrepreneurship currently in northern Ghana with a population of 1.5 million people. For five years now, our creative and innovative facility/space and resources can only host 15 young entrepreneurs for 6 to 8 months of training. We however we wish this campaign if successful would support us to increase our resources, space, tools and expertise to host and impact a 100 entrepreneurs each year  and other entrepreneurial learning events in the ecosystem/region to be able to start their own businesses, projects and also learn spacial skills which would empower them in finding jobs.  

Please read more and follow us here: www.hopinacademy.org 

Contributors would help us achieve the following below.

Hopin Academy would need an amount of 30,000 dollars of 50% of the amount to do the following below.

To be able to operate a 3-6 month long skill training for 100 young people in improving their skills to access jobs and also in starting their own small businesses. 

To provide some sort of seed capital ( Money) to the graduate entrepreneur’s to test, pilot or implement their ideas after incubation ( Training of the entrepreneurs ) in Hopin Academy.

To surround those entrepreneurs  with 10-20 successful mentors each year.

During the training young people are sent as interns to projects or business of their interest to meet change makers who have succeeded in their projects/businesses, This step helps them to gain a first had experience from the real working field and sharpens their mindset.  

To have funding for a two-year runway of the program while developing our model for sustainability for the continuation of working with young people many years after this funding for this project phases off.

To have physical space available for the program. our current space for meetings and training  needs more tools, learning materials and room for young people to work from, this would help young entrepreneurs to access working space of their ideas while they are still starting up with no or less capital.  

To have a strong management team who are typically proven entrepreneurs. We want to bring on board creative trainers as volunteers and team members to guide these young entrepreneurs.  

A less amount from what we seek would still be used to kick start what we envision to do and in addition our own funds secured organically for the past years of operations.

Hopin Academy would send a public appreciation with funder's profile and also through our newsletter and publications for your generous support with visuals and documentary of our new facility for entrepreneurs.  

As Africa and most developing countries are working towards moving from poverty and harsh economic issues, this program is set to solve the very problem by helping young people to grow with the mindset of independence by creating sustainable businesses, projects and to solving problems through technology and innovation. This also falls within the SDGs asHopin Academy approach focus on creative education, Skill development, economic growth, job creation and decent work.    

 

Hopin Academy has impact over 500 young people with modern skills to finding jobs since 2013.

We have impacted 90 young people to start sustainable micro enterprise’s to solving their community problems and creative livelihood for them.

We worked with the Ghanaian government to train 220 entrepreneurs and startups to access seed capital from the government

www.hopinacademy.org    

We hope this campaign succeeds for a great impact 

We have a growing pressure of young entrepreneurs falling out of the program as our current facility and resources are not available to handle more than 15 passionate entrepreneurs in an ecosystem of 1.5 million.   The new facility however would equip Hopin Academy to admit 100 young entrepreneurs each year instead of 15. 

Before Hopin Academy decided to embark on this fundraising. We asked ourselves of success rate?. 
We said to ourselves. We believe in humanity across the globe. And we have given it a short.Support our project by donating to us using the link below and kindly keep sharing to family and friends, this would help us reach our goal, every cent matters in making a real change. Thank you all as we Asking you.

We would be very grateful if you as will help share and spread this campaign to family and friends. 

Any cent would go far to making a great impact in the lives of young women/ Youth to move out of poverty by creating small businesses and projects to solving societal issues and making their personal lives better. Hopin Academy will be there as along a possible to keep on  serving young people to reaching their dreams and helping their country to move out of poverty.

story:
Square Tomato is a new web series presented by Sally Kettle – the first woman to row the Atlantic twice. This intrepid adventuress is on a mission to learn about the weird and the wonderful. Think Louis Theroux for kids.

Each episode will focus on mastering a new skill; it will be stuff we can all do, the first being growing square tomatoes.

Our audience is primarily 7-12yr olds so we want to work closely with schools. This is reflected in our funding structure.

For more information on getting involved with us as a school please contact us on squaretomatoes@googlemail.com

story:
My Story

Hi there! My name is Emma, and I'm in eighth grade. This year we are studying American History, and my history teacher is offering this amazing opportunity to go to Boston and New York over spring break to actually visit some of the historic places we will be learning about. These places include where the Salem Witch Trials took place, the Boston Harbor, where nearly 600,000 pounds of tea were dumped in 1773, Ellis Island, where thousands of immigrants arrived, and countless other things. We also get to go to Fenway Park, Yankee Stadium, Radio City Music Hall, Harvard, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, and so many more fun places. I also found out we will get to go to the Tenement Museum which I am SUPER excited about. You have to book that at least 10 months in advance! We get to stay for three nights in each city! I know it will be the most amazing trip ever. The one problem: the cost. Unfortunately, my family doesn't have the kind of money that will send me on the trip, and my parents were clear that I can't go unless I find the money elsewhere.

The Impact

I feel like this trip will really impact my history experience this year. It's so different being able to actually see something up close that you're learning about in the classroom than just reading about it. To walk where the American Revolution took place. To experience what it was like to live in the tenements. To feel the water that the members of the Boston Tea Party felt. I'm sooo excited!!!!! Plus, since I'm not going to be with my parents for an entire week, I think I will mature greatly.

What I Need

So, I need $2,800. Ouch. This will cover round-trip airfare, six nights at hotels, breakfast, lunch, dinner, transportation, entry fees to all the places we will be going, and the perks you get for donating. Keep reading to find out what those are! :D


Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to, you can always tell people to check my indiegogo page out! Even the smallest donation helps!

story:
THE MISSION: The Teeny Awards Recognition Program’s mission is to recognize and celebrate talented high school theatre students, encourage them to pursue their dreams as a career path to success, and to develop an understanding of the value of theatre arts in a well-rounded curriculum.  This program exists to bring attention to the hundreds of high school aged actors, musicians, production and stage technicians, who devote countless hours in perfecting their craft outside of the school day. The Teeny Awards is a sponsored project of the Islip Arts Council, a not-for-profit  501 (c) 3 . 

This program, currently in its 6th year, faces an uncertain future due to reduced funding in these hard economic times.

WHO WE ARE:  The Islip Arts Council is in its 38th year of supporting and presenting arts programs for the Town of Islip and the greater Long Island Community. The Arts Council brings quality programs to areas within our community for students and adults alike. The Islip Art Council is committed to continuing its nurturing of students to stay involved in the theater arts by recognizing their achievements and accomplishments which are truly deserving of the spotlight.

HOW YOU CAN HELP: In order to see this program through for 2014, funding is required to cover all costs associated with this project.  While personnel costs associated with this project are donated services, funding is required for space rental, printing and scholarship awards for students.  Our conservative goal based on last year’s budget is $5,000.  Any donation will assist us in continuing this worthwhile program for these deserving young artists who are often overlooked. Contributions for this project are tax deductible to the full extent permitted by law.

Please donate whatever you can in support of these future performing artists!
story_txt:
THE MISSION: The
Teeny Awards Recognition Program’s mission is to recognize and celebrate
talented high school theatre students, encourage them to pursue their dreams as
a career path to success, and to develop an understanding of the value of
theatre arts in a well-rounded curriculum. 
This program exists to bring attention to the hundreds of high school
aged actors, musicians, production and stage technicians, who devote countless
hours in perfecting their craft outside of the school day. The Teeny Awards is
a sponsored project of the Islip Arts Council, a not-for-profit  501 (c) 3 . 

This program, currently in its 6th
year, faces an uncertain future due to reduced funding in these hard economic
times.

story:
What This Is About

DeeTwenty Geeking Venue has sparked the intrigue of the Johannesburg geek and gamer community, by providing a safe space where adult geeks can spend their evenings and weekends in the company of fellow geeks, doing the things geeks love to do.

I'm Owen Swart, active member of the Joburg geek community for who knows how long. I started DeeTwenty late in 2013 as the result of a confluence between a lifelong desire to visit a place like DeeTwenty, and the opportunity to make it happen.

DeeTwenty has attracted the interest of our entire community, but I feel we have a wider contribution to make: a place to help protect and nurture geeky teens.

I remember being a geeky teen myself, having no safe space to go to play table-top games, cosplay or learn new geeky skills. My options were either to crowd around the living-room tables of my or my friends' parents', finding an abandoned classroom after school or just not doing it. That lack of a safe space meant my friends and I would become the targets of bullies and other people who didn't like what we were doing.

It breaks my heart to know that other geeky teens are having to go through the same thing, while us adult geeks get to enjoy the freedom and safety of a place like DeeTwenty Geeking Venue. But DeeTwenty isn't set up to cater to large numbers of younger geeks, as much as we may wish to.

We want to upgrade the facilities on offer: 

  • Improve security to keep teens and their possessions safe while they're geeking;
  • Upgrade the venue as a whole to accommodate more geeks, as well as expand the range of fun activities available;
  • Upgrade the kitchen so we can expand the variety and nutritional value of the meals we serve in our Power-Up Bar;
  • Open for longer hours, providing a space teens can visit every day after school if they want to;

Today's geeky kids are the intellectuals, philosophers, scientists, CEO's and leaders of tomorrow. We want to make sure they're able to expand and explore their interests and passions in a place we are proud to use ourselves.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we're hoping to raise, and how we want to spend it:

$30 000 is roughly R300 000, depending on the exchange rate. We want to spend it thus:

  • R60 000 on rent. By far our biggest expense. If we fall short of our goal, we'll still be putting as much of the funds we raise here as we can.
  • R50 000 on building an all-new, mini, outdoor laser-tag arena in the back yard, along with all the equipment necessary to encourage geek teens to get active, and have fun doing it!
  • R50 000 on hiring an assistant manager who can run the place when I'm off duty. We're looking at being open seven days a week, 10 hours a day. That's a full-time job for two people, assuming a few hours overlap between them during peak times. I'll continue to work for free (as I have done since we opened) until the business is profitable.
  • R40 000 on upgrading the Power-Up Bar. That includes buying new equipment so we can make a wider variety of healthy dishes, paying more attention to their nutritional value.

  • R80 000 on general upgrades to the club, including security, better tables, better lighting, erecting walls to create private rooms, upgrading the restrooms and so on.
  • R20 000 on start-up stock for our Armoury retail area, so we can provide the basic necessities geeks and gamers might need to do their thing, without needing to head off elsewhere to buy it.
As a contributor, not only are you helping us to create this safe, fun space for young geeks, but you're getting the opportunity to use the facility yourself! The evenings and weekends will still be dedicated to serving the greater geek community, and providing a place where all of us can do the things we love doing, and your contribution can buy you access!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute to this campaign for whatever reason, here are some things you can do:

  • Be a paying customer. Just come down to the club whenever you can with your friends, buy a Day Pass and a sandwich, enjoy the atmosphere we create and have a good time.
  • If you're too far away, but you believe in what we're doing: tell people about us! Share, post, tweet, blog, podcast, YouTube... do whatever you do to tell people about us. Every click helps to get the word out about what we're doing here.

story:
Short Summary

Penn Robotics both a class at Penn High School and a team that competes in an international robotics competition: the First Robotics Competition(FRC). Since our founding in 1997, we have been competing in FRC and have competed in the world competition many times. This year, we competed at the Crossroads Regional, at the Rose Hulman Institute of Technology, against almost 50 teams from 9 states. We also competed at the Boilermaker Regional at Purdue University against 40 other teams.  We fought with 3 Alliance partners and emerged victorious at both regional competitions. By winning these Regional Competitions, we have qualified for the World Championship in St. Louis, MO.

Check out the Highlights from the Regional here:


What We Need & What You Get

To accept this honor, and go to the World Championship, we must be able to pay for registration, transportation, and to stay in St. Louis for the Weekend. The Team this year is comprised of 24 students as well as almost 10 Mentors. In order to pay for this many people to attend this competition, we calculated the cost at $20,000. Going to the World Championship would be a great honor for many students, who have put in many hours to the project. If you contribute, we will represent you or your business at the World Championship. Either on our team T-shirts or on the robot itself. We always are grateful of our Donors and sponsors, and want to honor them at our competition, for the world to see. In the case that we do not reach our entire goal, we will either make up the difference with other grants and local sponsors, or in the case that we cannot go, the money will help fund the robotics program next year, and allow us to compete successfully next year.


The Impact

The First Robotics Competition is an international program that promotes engineering and Gracious Professionalism in both the community and within the teams. Students this year had 6 Weeks to design, build and Program their robot to accomplish the game Aerial Assist. The Students put in many hours to get this done, and have completed our robot. Our team has high hopes of attending the World Championship. Going and competing at the World Level would be the goal of the team, and, given our success at the regional competitions, we believe that we could do very well given the chance to compete. Penn Robotics has been successful in attending the World Championship many years in its long history, and we would like to continue this long tradition this year.


If you want to see the game this year, a link can be found here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f5zWzICG5to



Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot assist us financially, Please share the cause with others. If you cannot contribute to our team, we love other First Robotics Teams to have support. There are many teams throughout the country, and they always could use both motivational support as well as volunteer help. We encourage the community to help other teams around the world, and allow them to be successful.

story:
!!EMERGENCY UPDATE!!

On the night of July 3rd and early in the morning of July 4th, Ocracoke Island took a direct hit by Hurricane Arthur, a Category II storm. The winds, upwards of 100 mph, caused damage all over the island, including damage to the Wilma Lee.  The boat is OK, but we suffered a broken boom, damage to both the port and starboard rails and one or more dislodged cleats.  We are awaiting a USCG inspection to know more.

Our insurance would cover a catastrophic event, but fortunately (and unfortunately) this damage is not catastrophic - just costly.  We will now need additional funds to repair this damage, in addition to the badly needed sail replacement that this campaign focused on at the start.

Please keep a watch out for additional information and in the meanwhile, we are grateful for your support for our boat and this program, as we try to work our way over another hurdle.

We will stand by all of the gifts listed in this campaign, but may have to substitute or postpone some of them until this new challenge is cleared.

Thank you for your support!

Who We Are:

Ocracoke Alive is an Ocracoke-based, non-profit organization which is dedicated to the enrichment of life on Ocracoke island by producing and promoting artistic and educational programs for residents and visitors.

Among our several projects is the operation and maintenance of the historic sailing boat, the Skipjack Wilma Lee.  The Wilma Lee is a 50 foot wooden oystering sloop originating from the Chesapeake Bay, now sailing out of Ocracoke's Silver Lake harbor.

Long-term, this project will combine the Wilma Lee, her crew and island resources in a broad educational program, as an enhancement to the public and private school classroom experience.  We are currently working with the University of North Carolina's LEARN NC to produce model curriculum linked to Ocracoke Island and the Wilma Lee.

We are currently offering, three days a week, free dockside talks aboard the Wilma Lee, focusing on Ocracoke history and culture, the story of the Wilma Lee and Pirate Lore, true and otherwise.  Arrrrr...

Ocracoke Alive is also known for producing the annual Ocrafolk Festival, now in its fifteenth year, which brings great music and people together every spring for a three day music, arts  and storytelling extravaganza.

And this year, we are producing the musical play, "A Tale of Blackbeard" which will show live on stage, every Monday throughout the summer season, at the Ocracoke Community Center.


The problem:  The Wilma Lee needs new sails.

When we accepted the gift of the Wilma Lee, we knew we were accepting a very valuable asset, but also taking on a huge liability.  We have applied for and received grant funding from the Outer Banks Community Foundation, from Saltwater Connections and from LEARN NC. 

That support has moved us in the right direction, though we didn't anticipate that the sails would need to be replaced this soon.  We've had them repaired and we'll be able to get through another sailing season, but the reality is they're going, going....gone.

So we are asking for your help... and we've got great gifts to recognize your generosity. 


Please.

Read.

On...


What We Need

The Wilma Lee carries about 1,700 square feet of sail, including the main and the jib.  That's a lot of sail.  We've priced out replacement and found a really, really good deal at just over $9,000.  We also need a sail cover, which will bring us up to the $10,000 we are aiming for.  It is, in fact, the lack of a sail cover for the many years she was rigged prior to our acquisition, that accelerated the deterioration of the sails.

What You Get

Please take a look at our thank-you gifts listed below. Different gifts accompany the various levels of donations.  Because this is, after all, a Sailing Boat...we are able to offer some pretty exciting thank-yous to our partners in this venture.

Please note that most of the perks involve a cruise aboard the Wilma Lee.  In all cases, cruises are subject to certain conditions, including available seating on the boat, regular and special scheduling and, of course, weather conditions.  We will do everything possible to accommodate your schedule and to assure that you have a great experience.  Regularly scheduled cruise perks are redeemable for up to one year after the end of our campaign.  Please contact us for more information, as it may relate to your particular level of support.

story:
Becoming homeless in 15 minutes

In a nutshell:

--Two families lost their homes and all their belongings to fire.

--Property and fire insurance has never been available to them.

--All adults in the community of 150 people will together rebuild the two homes, even though this means a year of extra toil on top of their daily work.

--The homes are made of jungle plants, in a design used for thousands of years.

--Donations will enable the community to hire workers from other villages to help, pay government fees for replanting royal palms used in roofs, and enable the two families to begin replacing the lost bedding, school supplies, handicraft materials and other possessions that were burned.

My family (including two teen sons) were visiting the village by chance when a hut caught fire. We ran frantically with everyone to scoop buckets of water from the river, and afterwards saw how devastated the close-knit community was. We asked the chief how we could help and he said if people were able to donate funds, this would go a long way to restoring their community.

Here is the back story:

The biggest celebration in an Embera tribal community comes when a new hut is completed and one of the families at last has a home. That's because it has taken six months of hard work by every adult in the village to make it ready. As simple as these village huts on stilts may appear, made out of palm leaves, jungle tree branches, bamboo and twine, they require many steps of complex preparation and design, using skills passed on through generations.

But the thatched huts don't last long when they catch fire. These villagers have no fire hydrants, no fire extinguishers and no fire insurance, and when a home burns down, the financial loss is total.

Such a disaster happened in late December in the Panamanian jungle village of Puru, when a fire consumed first one hut and quickly another, along with everything inside. It began on a quiet afternoon when two children, 4 and 7 years old, played with matches while alone for only a moment. Thankfully, the children escaped unhurt, although two men putting out the fire suffered burns that are still healing. Nothing like this had happened in the villagers' memories.

The villagers are Embera tribe members and inhabited Central America long before Spanish colonizers came to the area. Much of mainstream Panamanian society has looked down on such communities for their traditional ways. Villagers live in nature and are self-sufficient. In Puru, they grow a few crops, keep hens, catch fish from the river and use what the jungle has to offer for foods, medicines, canoes, tools, handicrafts and inks to paint body tattoos, as well as to construct huts, their most precious of all.

In recent years, they have welcomed tourists as a way of generating income for an easier life. They may buy motors for their canoes, fishing nets, cooking utensils and required uniforms and supplies for children attending the village school. For tourists, they explain about their lifestyle, do a music and dance show and sell their beautiful handicrafts of bracelets, baskets and carvings.

Every penny you contribute will reach the Puru Embera tribe; my family has already donated and will pay all administration costs. Anyone wanting to check out the village can Google “Embera Puru” and see the tours organized by Garceth, who grew up in a different Embera village, and Anne, an American who married an Embera man. They both know about and welcome this campaign. And as for the villagers, they would love to have you visit one day.

story:
Kids' Canvas started over 4 years ago as a part-time, play and arts-based preschool for children 2-5 years old. We now operate 5 days/wk offering theater, music, visual art, outdoor time and lots of play. We are expanding to a new location where we will operate a full time daycare to serve working parents, while continuing our arts program. We are located in Bushwick, Brooklyn, an area with daycares primarily serving low-income residents. Kids' Canvas is independent and does not have income restrictions.

Our staff currently consists of me, Silvia Tripoli, currently enrolled in a Master's program in Early Childhood Education; Robert Greene, theater teacher with a Master's degree in Drama Education; and Frank Rathbone, musician and music teacher. Our expansion will require us to hire 3-5 additional teachers and staff, creating more jobs in our neighborhood.

The New Space

I have signed a lease on a new construction building just a couple of blocks from our current location. We will have 2 classrooms, which will more than double our capacity of children and our hours will increase. The landlord is doing some of the work needed to get licensed as a daycare, but there is a lot that we need to contribute. We are looking to raise $30,000 to pay for:
  • architect fees for floorplans and submissions to Dept of Buildings
  • contractors and materials to outfit the bathrooms and kitchenettes, install floors, ceilings, electrical wiring and fixtures
  • materials for classrooms: tables, chairs, shelves, cubbies, books, art supplies, musical instruments
  • office supplies: 2 computers, filing cabinets, shelving
  • vertical garden planters
  • licensing fees
Our fundraising event held in May 2014 raised $1500. The online campaign in summer 2013 raised $800 of which $400 was spent on inspections. We still need $28,100 to reach our goal. Indiegogo and Fractured Atlas keep a percentage of the funding, so we are aiming for $30,000 to raise the $28,100.

I have put in over $16,000 towards security deposit and architect fees. Please help up raise the rest!

Every dollar counts and will help get us closer to what we need. If we don't reach our goal, we will be looking for loans to complete the project. If we exceed our goal, we can purchase better equipment and more materials for our children. There is no limit to how great we can make our space.

Please help us reach our goal! Every dollar counts and is appreciated. If you cannot contribute financially, help us get the word out. Share our campaign!

Thank you!!
story_txt:
Kids' Canvas started over 4 years ago as a part-time, play and arts-based preschool for children 2-5 years old. We now operate 5 days/wk offering theater, music, visual art, outdoor time and lots of play. We are expanding to a new location where we will operate a full time daycare to serve working parents, while continuing our arts program. We are located in Bushwick, Brooklyn, an area with daycares primarily serving low-income residents. Kids' Canvas is independent and does not have income restrictions.Our staff currently consists of me, Silvia Tripoli, currently enrolled in a Master's program in Early Childhood Education; Robert Greene, theater teacher with a Master's degree in Drama Education; and Frank Rathbone, musician and music teacher. Our expansion will require us to hire 3-5 additional teachers and staff, creating more jobs in our neighborhood. The New Space
I have signed a lease on a new construction building just a couple of blocks from our current location. We will have 2 classrooms, which will more than double our capacity of children and our hours will increase. architect fees for floorplans and submissions to Dept of Buildings

materials for classrooms: tables, chairs, shelves, cubbies, books, art supplies, musical instruments
office supplies: 2 computers, filing cabinets, shelving
vertical garden planters
licensing fees

Please help up raise the rest!Every dollar counts and will help get us closer to what we need. If we don't reach our goal, we will be looking for loans to complete the project. If we exceed our goal, we can purchase better equipment and more materials for our children. There is no limit to how great we can make our space. Please help us reach our goal! story:
Thank you so much for checking out my Indiegogo campaign.  My name is Jacinda Wilcox and I am trying to start DC CRAFT, Creative Reuse Art Fair for Teachers.  Until July 2013, I taught Visual Arts in DC for 7 years both in Charter and DC Public Schools.  My last few years in DCPS I was able to offer support for my colleagues by helping with curriculum writing, planning district-wide professional development, and organizing the district’s end of year Visual Arts Showcase. After staying home to raise my newborn daughter I felt a desire to continue to help my colleagues who are working in low-income communities. 

While working in DC, I rarely had the things I needed to be successful. I often spent my own money and received lots of donations from friends. Most of all, I had to be creative with materials. Working in a STEM school, I learned that using recyclable materials added a new level to the education I was able to give my students; they became engineers and problem solvers when I gave them reusable materials for creating. We learned lots of innovative techniques together.

Creative reuse is a great way to reduce waste and create art at a lower cost.  Using materials found around the home and office, children can create sculptures, mixed media artworks, collages, and printmaking activities.  This type of art making often requires high levels of innovation and creativity and is something the children can easily practice on their own time.

DC CRAFT will be a free one-day event held in collaboration with local arts, education, environmental, and creative reuse agencies. The event will provide professional development, networking opportunities, and supplies to teachers who work without many of the things they need. By helping educators get the materials and information they need to be successful, DC CRAFT will also reach hundreds or even thousands of needy students in the DC area.

We need $3000 for the following:

  • Rental of a storage unit for donated materials
  • Rental of a location to hold the event
  • Promotional materials, mailings, and website fees to publicize our event
  • Continental breakfast for attendees and volunteers
  • Printed materials for the day of the event

Any funds raised will be used in hosting this event. Leftover funds will be used to support one needy teacher's trip to the National Art Education Association's National Convention in 2015. 

Want to help? Check out our Craft in DC Blog for ways to donate items if you’re in the DC area. Share our blog and Indiegogo campaign with your friends, family, and coworkers.

Thanks for your support, lets beautify the earth and encourage our kids and their teachers!

CRAFT in DC Blog: 

http://craftindc.wordpress.com

story:
Short Summary

We are going to Spain and some kids from Spain are coming here!

This is the sixth year that 7th grade students from Oyster-Adams Bilingual School in Washington DC have been doing cultural exchanges with Colegio Vizcaya in Bilbao.

The families of our 7th grade students will host 18 children and two teachers from Bilbao for two weeks in March and, 18 of our 7th graders and two teachers will go to Bilbao in May. 

 

What We Need

Money to help show the Spanish exchange students around the Washington DC area and to provide travel scholarships for the students who need financial assistance. 

 

The Impact

Cultural exchange programs are enriching activities for students.  The students not only learn about the culture of another country but also have the opportunity to perfect their bilingualism and make friends forever.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please visit the school’s websites for more information and help us spread the word!.

http://www.colegiovizcaya.net/

http://oysteradamsbilingual.org/

story:
On April 19th, we’re going to give young kids of color the foundational knowledge that they’ll need to build their own excitement around programming. We’re going to give them a boost. 


WHAT YOU CAN DO....contribute funds to help us feed the kids and offer them some great incentives for participating!  Our event is this SATURDAY April 19th, 2014 @ 9am - can you help us raise $500 for food and gifts! 


“Every month, the tech industry adds about 9,600 jobs to the U.S. economy. By 2018, it will have added another 1.2 million new jobs, boasting an average salary of $78,000.

Women and minorities are underrepresented in the tech sector. For example, women make up just 22% of the computing workforce, and Latino and African-American workers each make up less than 5%.


It is no coincidence that of all STEM courses (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics), computer science is the only high school subject to have seen a drop in participation since 1990. This has been a loss to our youth, and to a booming tech industry starved for talent.” - Codenow.org


“…growing economic inequality promises to have deleterious impacts on our society if left unaddressed. Individuals and families left behind might earn their way to better standards of living – but only if they have the skills to compete in a global economy.” - jointcenter.org


“...By learning this highly valuable and relevant 21st century skill, these young people are shifting the trajectory of their futures and transforming their relationships with their communities and their country.” - Yeswecode.org

story:
What We Do

18 months ago, Laurel and David launched www.voicescienceworks.org as a free online resource for all voice lovers. Today the site has over 30 free tutorial pages and draws 20,000+ visitors a week. Along with the free information offered on the site we also provide group workshops, one on one lessons, vocal ensemble retreats, educational webinars and performances as vocal artists.

The information on the site draws on research from the fields of Vocal Performing Arts, Logopedics, Speech and Hearing Science, Audiology, Neurology, Laryngology, and Otology, and relies on knowledge of vocal anatomy, physiology, biomechanics, perceptual-motor learning principles, acoustics, the physics of sound, and vocal pedagogy and practice. What does that boil down to? The nitty gritty of how we make sound and how we teach people to make the sounds they want to make.

Because all of this information in it’s raw form can often feel alienating and uninviting, the goal of our website is to translate the important parts into bite-size bits. VoiceScienceWorks is place where science can be fun, beautiful, communicative, and accessible to all.

What We Want to Do

To date, all of our work has been a gift to the voice community. But now the demand for what we’re offering has grown into a small business. We want to move at a quicker pace, add more complete information to the website and add more people to our team.

Our first fundraising goal is to raise $10,000 to launch the following projects in the next 6 months:

  • Create and share 15 more free content pages with original clarifying images  (including free tutorials on vowel perception, vocal registers, singingin multiple styles, vibrato, and the science of hearing)
  • Create and share a brand new online course introducing how you, too, can play with voice analyzer software
  • Create and share 5 educational videos, the beginning of VoiceScienceWorks video series
  • Create and share the first season of our new podcast Translation Station: From Science to Pedagogy
  • Create and share our second online publication The Unfiltred Source: an eZine for the Communal Voice Lover
  • Begin production on our first book: The Smart Singer’s Revolution
  • Add a member to our team to help update references, courses, conferences and resources on the site

 

Why it's Important

The voice is an instrument we all share, we’re all curious about, and yet most people feel alienated from. The voice is the most expressive and diverse instrument on the planet. The voice tells you how you are and who you are and every emotion you have passes through your voice. Because it is an instrument that can’t be directly seen, touched, or controlled, most voice users face frustration and confusion when learning how to make the sounds they want to make.

We have heard feedback from beginning voice users, professional singers, voice teachers, choir directors, speech therapists, university professors, researchers, actors, and composers that the information and resources on our website provides tools that they can immediately start working with, empowers their learning process, and helps them narrow down other confusing information they might come across.

No other website is currently offering this unique information, and for free! We believe it is a right of all voice users to have access to information that is accurate, clarifying, empowering and adds joy to their vocal journeys.

 

Other Ways to Get Involved

Share this campaign with fellow voice lovers!

Join our Newsletter to stay in touch with constant updates and new materials on the site
https://visitor.r20.constantcontact.com/d.jsp?llr=b6nvtaxab&p=oi&m=1124228315041&sit=4uwddcpkb&f=a88594dd-05a4-463c-9e79-a6f68fe7ba34

Contact us about being a guest author for our eZine publication, book reviews page or blog article voicescienceworks@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Hello, we are a group of improvisers based in Bucharest, Romania. We play, teach and also live by art and improvisation. We’ve traveled the world and explored how improv and art changed people, communities, lives, and we’ve assumed the mission that we’ll bring this to “our people” by opening Recul Theatre and School.

Recul School and Theatre needs a new place to grow and to help others grow. In the next three months, we have to move our entire activity from the rented house in which we’re in right now, to a newer, bigger, brighter home.

And for our family, as well as it is for every other family, a new home means: first of all a new rent, moving costs, improvement costs, furniture and new equipment.

This is where YOU come in! We need your help to open the new Recul Theatre and School! By doing this you’ll be part of a movement that’s just starting, you’ll be able to get front row seats to our performances, special classes for you and your peeps, and some of you will get the chance to have a special part in our shows and theatre.

Also, you’ll be supporting a movement that can help our community grow and our society to prosper.

Discovering the world through the eyes of a performer at Recul means discovering the world through curiosity and not suspicion. In our country, we’re still struggling with the old mentality and this is affecting the new generation. Kids in schools don’t have the chance to explore their feelings, to be authentic and have courage. Through our classes, we can reach this potential and much more. By supporting us, with the classes that we’ll address to kids, you’ll be investing in them as well.

In the next three months while you’ll be spending a cozy Christmas (we hope), we’ll be creating, designing, wrapping, packing, moving, cleaning, painting and opening the new Recul School, a place of:

Theatre: a new training and teaching place for performers in Romania and not only, an incubator for improv, theatre, sketch comedy and much more, a place where any group can train, discover and develop new art and shows, a network of teachers and a space for connecting  passionate people from Romania and all over the world.

Intuitive Learning: a multidisciplinary curriculum with a core on improvisation and art as a method of teaching. Our teachers will open classes like: learn a foreign language through conversation and improv; discover the beauty of math through improv; boost your self-esteem through musical improv;

But here’s the thing, we can’t open a school and a new theatre without you. And this is your unique chance to be part of a group that’s opening a school and a theatre. Here’s our plan:

What We Need & What You Get

We have three months to move everything that we have in the old Recul Theatre, find a new place that can host the theatre and Recul School.

We’ll be moving in a new place downtown Bucharest with easy access from anywhere (in the world - all roads will lead to Recul).

We’ll rent a house that has the following details:

Recul Theatre: A performance room big enough, around 115 square meters,  where we can build 60 seats for the audience, build a stage, lights & sounds equipped and ready for magical improv shows.

Recul School: Four separate rooms, not as big as the performance room but around 20 square meters, in the house where, yes, you guessed it, magic will happen. It’s where we’ll create the space for improvisation classes and intuitive learning.

Bar space: an extra room, 65 square meters, and terrace, for all the geeky improv talks before and after the shows.

For all our wishes above, the rent, downtown Bucharest, is around 2500 Euros/month (for all the Eastern Europe people, this should sound about high, for other more advanced countries where this rent might seem low, you have to imagine that the minimum monthly wage for the 8hours work day in Romania is around 300 Euros)....yes… we know, 2500 Euros/month is a big deal in this case and this is just rent.

But hey, we’re improvisers and we’re sure you guys will have our back.

And because you’ll do that, we generously prepared some special perks for you. We’re very excited about the limited ones such as:

The cultural remedy kit: a special magic box that contains natural cultural remedies for every sign of ache caused by the lack of art in your life.

Special limited edition merchandise: we prepared a special line of T-shirts, handmade objects, posters.

Guaranteed presence in Recul Theatre: you’ll be here, with us, all the time. On the wall of fame dedicated to the supporters and on the list of “go to” names we’ll use in our improvised shows. Yes, you heard that right! If you decide to go for this perk we’ll give life to characters named after you in our improv shows.

story:
The book is now publicly available, get it at http://hdv470-7.com

 

We’re publishing a German Army Regulation of 1941 about the Medium Tank Company (Mittlere Panzerkompanie)

The H.Dv. 470/7 - Die mittlere Panzerkompanie from May 1941 is a key Army regulation for the German Panzer force following the successful campaigns in Poland, the Low Countries and France. It encompasses topics such as tank crew specialization, training, formations, how to engage enemy positions and tanks, as well as a complete breakdown of the tank company’s force strength.

This book will feature the German original text side by side to the English translation to give you the most authentic historic reproduction of this document. The translation itself is kept as close and accurate to the original as possible, with additional remarks where necessary when the ‘military German’ from the 1940s provided a more ambiguous explanation than perhaps intended. Likewise, the formatting of the document will base itself on the original document.

During our research on this document, which we also conducted at the German Military Archive in Freiburg, we uncovered plenty of additional information that might prove of interest to you. These were also added to provide additional contextual information and clarifications where necessary, including a breakdown of the main Panzer variants used by the Germans during Operation Barbarossa. As always, a full range of sources is given.

As our collaborators on this project, Major Nicholas "The Chieftain" Moran (US Army Armor Branch) reviewed our translation. Equally, Dr. Roman Töppel, German Military Historian and Eastern Front expert reviewed our Glossary and summaries of the Panzer I to IV.

 

What You Get

  • The English translation of the original text with annotations and a wide range of remarks for more information on content and the translation itself.
  • ​The German text annotated with our remarks where necessary.
  • 262 pages* of Panzer goodness.
  • A list of titles of all referenced Army & Service regulations, since these are only mentioned by number in the original text.
  • A glossary of important German military terminologies with short explanation.
  • Visualization of the composition of a German Medium Tank Company from 1941.
  • List of equivalent ranks in the German, US and Red Army for officers, NCOs & enlisted men.
  • Short summaries and technical data on the Panzer I to IV.
  • Of course, a bibliography.

* Plus/Minus a few pages in the final edit.

 

Risks and Challenges

While the text is sitting at 98% completion and we are ready to put the final stamp, certain challenges present themselves which we want to share with you.

  • This is our first project of this nature. We have spent many hours and days planning this project since we started it in Spring 2019. During this time, we have gone over the document countless times to fix errors, provide a legible but authentic body and provide all additional information that a reader might find beneficial. The text has also gone through an editorial review. As with all things however, errors (for example in spelling) can creep into any piece of work. Likewise, the original formatting of the original will be kept, resulting in a handful of pages that look somewhat 'empty'.
  • Self-publishing this book is quite an undertaking. While we could go hands-off and just hand it over to a publisher, we don’t think this is the best solution for you or for us. The price would rise, the timetable would be pushed back many months and, in the end, we end up dependent on someone else. As such, we’ve tried to find the best way of self-publishing this book by printing the sold copies after the campaign ends (hopefully) successfully and shipping them out by a fulfillment center. This gives us extra work but ensures a fair price and hopefully a speedy arrival of your book (see ETA in the perks). We have done our homework and that is half the battle but, in all fairness, we are new to this which might mean that the unexpected or unforeseen might occur.
  • Due to our choice to self-publish, shipping anywhere outside the US is difficult as the shipping prices over the fulfillment center vary drastically. While we had initially limited orders due to only the US because of this, based on your feedback and demand we have now changed this with an extra perk offering paperback for EU countries, Switzerland and Norway. The price does vary from US-based orders (where our book is printed), as the books will be sent to the EU, and then manually shipped to all of you. Shipping is INCLUDED in the pledging price. For those of you that pledged for a signed copy before, you can still change this selection back to a simple paperback. Equally, for those of you that pledged for the EBook version, you can now also change to a paperback if you amend your order.
  • Privacy notice: Your shipping addresses will be processed by the fulfillment center and us.

 

TEAM

Bernhard "MHV" Kast

Bernhard Kast better known on YouTube as Military History Visualized with 485 000 Subscribers and 54 Million Views. Bernhard has a M.A. in History and M.Sc. in Computer Science both from the University of Salzburg Austria.

Christoph "Bismarck" Bergs

Christoph Bergs better known on YouTube as Military Aviation History with 159 000 Subscribers and 21 Million Views. Christoph has a MA in History and Int. Relations from Dundee University. He is currently a PhD Candidate at King’s College London.

 

Supporting Experts

Nicholas "Chieftain" Moran

Nicholas "The Chieftain" Moran - US Army Armor Branch Officer and Director of Military Relations at Wargaming America. Nicholas is the author of Can Openers: The Development of American Anti-Tank Gun Motor Carriages (2017). Nicholas read our translation so that it is up to scratch when it comes to modern military terminology and helped us avoid various pitfalls.

Dr. Roman Töppel

Dr. Roman Töppel - Freelance Military Historian, best known for being one of four editors of the Critical Edition of Mein Kampf and the book Kursk 1943: The Greatest Battle in the Second World War (2018). Roman reviewed our German glossary and summaries of the Panzer I and IV.
story_txt:
The book is now publicly available, get it at http://hdv470-7.com
 
We’re publishing a German Army Regulation of 1941 about the Medium Tank Company (Mittlere Panzerkompanie)
The H.Dv. 470/7 - Die mittlere Panzerkompanie from May 1941 is a key Army regulation for the German Panzer force following the successful campaigns in Poland, the Low Countries and France. It encompasses topics such as tank crew specialization, training, formations, how to engage enemy positions and tanks, as well as a complete breakdown of the tank company’s force strength.
This book will feature the German original text side by side to the English translation to give you the most authentic historic reproduction of this document. The translation itself is kept as close and accurate to the original as possible, with additional remarks where necessary when the ‘military German’ from the 1940s provided a more ambiguous explanation than perhaps intended. Likewise, the formatting of the document will base itself on the original document.
During our research on this document, which we also conducted at the German Military Archive in Freiburg, we uncovered plenty of additional information that might prove of interest to you. These were also added to provide additional contextual information and clarifications where necessary, including a breakdown of the main Panzer variants used by the Germans during Operation Barbarossa. As always, a full range of sources is given.
As our collaborators on this project, Major Nicholas "The Chieftain" Moran (US Army Armor Branch) reviewed our translation. Equally, Dr. Roman Töppel, German Military Historian and Eastern Front expert reviewed our Glossary and summaries of the Panzer I to IV.
 
What You Get


The English translation of the original text with annotations and a wide range of remarks for more information on content and the translation itself.
​The German text annotated with our remarks where necessary.
262 pages* of Panzer goodness.
A list of titles of all referenced Army & Service regulations, since these are only mentioned by number in the original text.
A glossary of important German military terminologies with short explanation.
Visualization of the composition of a German Medium Tank Company from 1941.
List of equivalent ranks in the German, US and Red Army for officers, NCOs & enlisted men.
Short summaries and technical data on the Panzer I to IV.
Of course, a bibliography.

* Plus/Minus a few pages in the final edit.

This gives us extra work but ensures a fair price and hopefully a speedy arrival of your book (see ETA in the perks). We have done our homework and that is half the battle but, in all fairness, we are new to this which might mean that the unexpected or unforeseen might occur.

While we had initially limited orders due to only the US because of this, based on your feedback and demand we have now changed this with an extra perk offering paperback for EU countries, Switzerland and Norway. story:
I have a strong desire to complete my studies and fulfill my dream and my ambition in science and knowledge, where you want to get a PhD degree in accounting and finance or something like that in one of the strongest universities. Because this is the way of great benefit to the development of my skills and experience in accounting, administrative and other social benefits, which are in the interest of society and the level of development of its members, and leave a mark in life; but the living conditions we are living under the blockade imposed on the Gaza Strip, in addition to the costs of the study of these conditions and others may become an obstacle in front of me to continue learning. 

I got a master's degree from the Islamic University, Department of Accounting and finance with very good grade, and bachelor's degree in accounting from the Islamic University with excellent grade ,

I got many training courses in the field of accounting, management, computer and so on in a variety of fields.

So I hope that you accept my request to help me.

story:
Family, Friends, Fraternal Brothers, Colleagues,

Unfortunately my collegiate career is coming to an end this semester because I am graduating. Along the way I have met many exceptional people and had the time of  my life. Help me celebrate the end of an era with ONE LAST COLLEGE BANGER.

Donations for this campaign will go towards purchasing party supplies. The theme for the party may include awareness for some social injustice. The party is tentatively planned for April 24th at a yet to be determined location. If you have any questions about this campaign please contact me directly.

Here are some reasons why you should donate:

  • live vicariously through my college experience
  • you could probably get this tax deductible
  • what else would you waste your money on
  • possible reward tiers
  • donate money instead of sending a care package (family/relatives)
  • improve your sense of well being/personal satisfaction
  • put this on your resume
  • be a part of something bigger than yourself
  • get invited to a party
  • feel like you contributed to my education
Thank you for considering my campaign. I'll leave everyone with a inspirational quote.

"You gotta fight, for your right, to party!" - Beastie Boys

story:
Short Summary

Hi! We are Mie and Guillermo, we are both undergraduate students reading Biology and Maths respectively. This summer we are volunteering for a month in Yueyang, in Hunan province, China, where we will be teaching English in a volunteer-run camp in Yueyang Sunny English Training school.

This will hopefully make a great impact on the kid's lives as achieving a higher level of English enables them to aspire to better jobs, widening their opportunities but also to enjoy and understand a culture different from their own.

However, we would like to go a step further, and create a more long-term impact for the learning center, which is noticeably low on resources. It manages to go on due to the time and effort of volunteers, but it does not have spare money to invest on teaching facilities. Thus, we aim to raise some money that will be used in buying a pair of projectors and some other material, such as books.

After this month we will be travelling to Vietnam and Cambodia, places from which we wish to be able to offer our donors some interesting perks!

What we need

The majority of the funds will be invested into the acquisition of two new projectors in China, some material for teaching and English read for teenagers.

A minor part of the funds will be diverted to the purpose of documenting our journey and sharing our experience, specifically a camera (nothing too fancy, probably a SJ4000, nothing above $100, just something to capture the moments) and a small 10” laptop or chromebook (with a cost not exceeding $250) to update our blog during the journey.

Perks

To make it less painful to give money away, we offer a series of perks which we believe can be interesting:

Want to know first hand about the daily running of the camp and the visions of the children about it? Receive a letter from a child, thanking you for the donation and telling you about their experiences in the camp.

Have you ever wondered what the thoughts of a Chinese man about polygamy would be? Or what does a Vietnamese sailor think about fish farms?:

Now we give you the chance to solve these doubts that keep you awake at night. You can buy questions that we will translate into the proper language and get answered by the locals.  During the trip, we will be uploading all the answers either in video with subtitles or in written format (if video is not possible) to our blog. There, you will also find some examples of questions, which you can sponsor if you are not inspired now.

Want to make you home a bit more international? We will send you a postcard from wherever you prefer in our itinerary (check it out here)!

Is a postcard too dull for you and you want a more intense experience of China? Yueyang, or more accurately, Jun Shan island, a few km away from Yueyang is the original place of the famous Junshan Yingzhen tea. Why not try this rare tea, regarded as one of the three most famous teas in China (as a historical note, it was Mao’s favourite)?

Also, we have devoted a long time planning our trip through Vietnam and Cambodia and we know how tedious and daunting it can be. We therefore offer all the information concerning hostels, transport, visas, etc. we gather throughout our journey. This will be accompanied with the possibility of talking to us via Skype after our trip so that you can ask us any doubts in relation with planning your adventure (you can find our planned itinerary at our blog).

Finally, if you have any other request (eg: some Chinese recipe) or would like any other item that we could get somewhere in our journey, (Chinese snake wine, Vietnamese typical clothing at Hoi An…) please contact us at guilleandmie@gmail.com and we will arrange its price if possible.

The Impact

With regards to China we are hoping to generate a positive local impact on the lives of children attending the course. Not just on an academic level, in which their knowledge of the language will be enhanced, but also on the integral formation of the children. It is one thing to be introduced to the English language, but it is another more motivating experience to interact actively with the culture. Thus, we will carry out activities to make children understand why it is important to learn English, in order to make the process more enjoyable for them and to instill interest and self-motivation for learning.  On top of everything, the activities that will carried out involve taking the leap forward in oral skills and losing the fear of speaking out loud. Finally, with Guillermo's musical knowledge we will try and create a choir, as learning songs is a fun and simple way to learn about Western culture!

The acquisition of projectors will have a significant effect on the long-term of the classroom, as it adds color to the lectures, and allows for much more student participation.

Lastly, through our blog and our narration of the experience we aim to inspire more people to dare to explore South East Asia in a more personal and local way, as well as make the point that culture influences our perspective, as we hope the answers to the questions will show.

Other Ways You Can Help

In you cannot contribute with money that's fine! It will be enough that you share this with your friends or anybody that you think could be interested in our project! Besides, if you have any suggestion that you think might improve our project, please do not hesitate to contact us at guilleandmie@gmail.com.

Also, if you have any English book or dictionary that you do not want please send it to Guillermo Pascual, St Catherine's College, Oxford OX1 3UJ and we will make sure that Chinese children will be able to enjoy it. If you have any doubt please contact us.

Last but not least if you are a student in the UK and would like to spend your summer volunteering in China, we highly recommend you contact IVSC, a student run organization which will put you in contact with summer camps in China.

story:
Cette campagne est terminée, mais une nouvelle est en cours 

Notre nouvel objectif est financer des bourses pour permettre aux étudiants méritants de passer gratuitement l'examen surveillé, de soutenir le MOOC par exemple en continuant le développement des cours en anglais.

_______________________________________

Présentation du projet

Le MOOC Gestion de projet est le premier MOOC certificatif créé en France : 62.000 inscriptions ont été enregistrées sur nos 5 éditions.

Notre objectif ? Donner à tous l’accès à une formation de qualité : Management des projets, démarches de gestion des risques, cahier des charges, évaluation d’impact... douze thématiques sont disponibles.


En plus des deux sessions annuelles du MOOC, les formations restent en accès libre en permanence. Ainsi, les statistiques de nos vidéos montrent que sur les 365 derniers jours, plus de 120.000 heures de cours ont été suivies.


Nous voulons maintenant, grâce à votre aide améliorer le site actuel gestiondeprojet.pm, 


À quoi servira la collecte ?

A reconcevoir et à héberger le site gestiondeprojet.pm sur un serveur plus puissant. Cela donnera accès à l’ensemble de la formation toute l’année, y compris en dehors des dates d’ouverture du MOOC. Sur le site on trouve les vidéos des formations, mais aussi des quiz, des modèles de documents pour la gestion de projet.

Le site aujourd'hui ..


Il nous manque 3.000 € pour démarrer le projet.

Si nous collectons plus de 3.000 €, voici ce que nous ferons : l'association "Les amis du MOOC GdP" qui gérera ces fonds pourra par exemple : développer de nouveaux modules de formation, promouvoir l'utilisation des données du MOOC GdP par des chercheurs, améliorer les plateformes de MOOC existantes en développant de nouvelles fonctions, créer des bourses d'examen supplémentaires (voir la contrepartie pour en savoir plus).

story:
Short Summary

Hi I'm Anibal Arroyo creator and artist of "Lil' Steve's Closet". Originally a high school class project, it has evolved to what it is today and that is, a huge milestone in my personal life as well as my artistic career. This story is loosely based on my eldest son Steve who when I  began this story was 5 years old -- he is now 16. I am particularly proud of this project, not only because it's my first solo project, but because its completion, like I mentioned before, literally represents a chapter of my life. I now wish to share my story with you and allow kids of all ages to know that they too can accomplish anything they want in life as long as they are determined. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $10,000 but to reach that goal we need your help. This will not only cover printing costs but also cover distribution costs, the purchase of ISBN numbers and  barcodes, promotional and advertisement materials, and shipping costs. The book will be available in both soft cover and special edition hard cover formats.

For your contributions you will receive great perks, including exclusive sketch cards with artwork based on the book, a coloring book set, gift cards and if that's not enough, send us a photo of yourself and the creator and artist will transform that into a one of a kind 8 1/2" X 11" black and white portrait.

The Impact

"Lil' Steve's Closet" is a project I literally poured my blood, sweat and tears into. The book is hand painted from cover to cover and it's a tale of youth, adventure, fantasy and a life lesson that is universal. The story behind its creation is a testament to the willpower and determination that lies within us all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Now, we do understand that some people may not be able to contribute at this point in time, but that doesn't mean that you can't help.

Help us spread the word by either word of mouth or directing people to this link. You can also log on to our website, www.masmediastudios.com follow us on twitter @MASMediaStudios and friend us on facebook @https://www.facebook.com/masmediastudios

Thank you for your support and contributions!

I now wish to share my story with you and allow kids of all ages to know that they too can accomplish anything they want in life as long as they are determined. What We Need & What You GetOur goal is $10,000 but to reach that goal we need your help. This will not only cover printing costs but also cover distribution costs, the purchase of ISBN numbers and  barcodes, promotional and advertisement materials, and shipping costs. The book will be available in both soft cover and special edition hard cover formats.For your contributions you will receive great perks, including exclusive sketch cards with artwork based on the book, a coloring book set, gift cards and if that's not enough, send us a photo of yourself and the creator and artist will transform that into a one of a kind 8 1/2" X 11" black and white portrait.The Impact"Lil' Steve's Closet" is a project I literally poured my blood, sweat and tears into. The book is hand painted from cover to cover and it's a tale of youth, adventure, fantasy and a life lesson that is universal. The story behind its creation is a testament to the willpower and determination that lies within us all.Other Ways You Can HelpNow, we do understand that some people may not be able to contribute at this point in time, but that doesn't mean that you can't help.Help us spread the word by either word of mouth or directing people to this link. You can also log on to our website, www.masmediastudios.com follow us on twitter @MASMediaStudios and friend us on facebook @https://www.facebook.com/masmediastudiosThank you for your support and contributions!

story:
Hello, my name is Jennifer. I am the mother of two wonderful children and I am a chronic cancer patient. My initial diagnosis was in 2001, my first relapse was in 2005/6, I have done countless treatments and procedures and it keeps coming back. My greatest wish at this time is to attend the graduations each of my children are having this year (only 4 weeks apart). One trip is 1,266 km each way, the other is 1,930 km each way.

         

Due to financial and health reasons, they have lived with their father since 2003. They moved to Kansas (USA) in 2006, I was in the process of my first re-diagnosis at this time. I am in the midst of another re-diagnosis now. My children are now grown and we are still close. 
When my son turned 18, he moved in with me, until he decided what he wanted to do. He moved back to Kansas and joined the National Guard. He is graduating Basic Training in April, in South Carolina.
My daughter is living with me now, but needs to return to Kansas for her high school graduation ceremony.

I have been on disability pension since late 2006. I am able to make ends meet, so long as I keep my budget tight and strict. This does not leave me much opportunity to splurge and unfortunately attending the graduations of my children falls under this category on my budget.

What We Need 

I have been working out a budget for the required transportation and shelter costs.

Son's graduation in South Carolina (my mother will accompany me): car rental (minimum 3 days , about $200-300+ insurance), gasoline for the car (I estimate $200-300 round trip), motel room (minimum 2 days, $100-200), food (for 2 people for 2-3 days, $60) = $560 to $860 +insurance
I am hoping this will be sufficient. This is a 2 day event and my plan is to leave home late Tuesday, arrive early Wednesday (Family events), Thursday is the graduation ceremony; leave South Carolina after the ceremony (and spending a small amount of time with my son), to arrive home early Friday morning.

     


Daughter's graduation in Kansas (mother will accompany me again): car rental (one week, $400-500+ insurance), gasoline for the car (I estimate $400-500 round trip), motel room (3 days, $250-300), food (for 4-6 days, $200). = $1250 to $1500 +insurance
The plan for this one is to leave home Thursday, drive through the night arrive in Kansas Friday; spend the day sleeping/resting, graduation on Saturday, leaving either Sunday or Monday (depending on amount of rest received). My daughter will drive back home with us.

     


Before her graduation, my daughter would like to attend her prom. We have been lucky enough to find dress & shoes second hand and I have found jewelry on clearance. Her entire prom attire has cost us $30. She has had to move back to Canada before expected, so now would like to return to Kansas for prom with her friends. She has friends she can stay with, but the flight there will cost $300-500.

This gives us a grand total of $2110 to 2860 (plus insurance on both rental cars) and of course, there are always unexpected costs that come up (I am hoping this will be less than $500 for both trips). We are only looking to raise $2000 of this, hoping that we can cover the rest without missing too many utility bills (water, electricity, gas). 

If we are unable to reach our goal, I will have to decide which graduation I can/should attend. If there is extra money raised, I will be donating to the local food bank. My mother volunteers there and we know many families who benefit from the great work they do.

The Impact

For me, it means a lot to be there for my children, to show them that I support them, to show them that I am proud of them.
I can not speak for my children, but I think it would be a negative impact to not have me in attendance at their graduations. Due to my cancer, they know there is a possibility that our time is limited. Knowing this, I try to make the best of my "healthy days" by spending time with my kids when I can. With my son being part of the American military now, I am not sure of often I will be able to see him. This scares me, as a mother.
I also don't want to have to tell my son about my most recent cancer relapse by mail, email or text message. I would rather tell him in person, for a change.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are links here to share this campaign with your friends and family, please pass this along, even if you are unable to assist us. 
All well wishes and prayers are welcome and appreciated as well.

story:
Summary

Colegio De La Estrella is a small school in Burol Main, Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines for children ages 3 to 15 usually born to parents belonging to the low and middle brackets of the low income earners. It started to operate with two-room classrooms and is presently occupying 11 classrooms.

Small fees are charged per pupil to help defray costs of operation. The faculty of instruction are given very little salaries. They handle tutorials just to add to their income. While the management expects to get some savings at the end of each school year, the scanty amounts are not often on hand or stated as receivables.

Despite the struggles Colegio De La Estrella went through, it manages to serve the student populace for the last 21 years. Now, in its 22nd year of operation, it still strives to offer quality but affordable education. Our graduates prove to be the top performing students in the secondary and tertiary schools they enroll in.

We strongly believe that we can prepare these potential leaders of our community or become competitive members of our society. We hope to continue providing them the best training they could get in the coming school years.

What We Need

  • Colegio De La Estrella is in need of $2,700. Less the processing fees, we will be able to restore/replace the termites-infested walls and ceilings and paint them.
  • This amount will enable us to repair as far as the hallways to prevent water leaks during the rainy days.
  • If ever we exceed our goal, we will purchase laboratory supplies to minimize on improvisation.

The Impact

Effective learning relies on many factors; one of which is the students’ immediate environment; the classrooms, and/or the whole school.

CDLE endeavors to prepare our students for the future as they are taught globally competitive skills and led in the acquisition of the right attitudes in life so that they become responsible citizens of our nation.

With this as our mission, we will be providing our students with more conducive environments and inspire them more as they interact within the confines of their classrooms.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has resources to give back but that does not mean you can’t help out. Another way you can aside from donating is by spreading the word; help us reach other people that can donate.

We implore you to SHARE this to family, friends, colleagues, church and/or civic groups or any others that you think may participate.

SHARE on facebook, twitter, your personal website or blog or even email our story out with the campaign’s link. Use #CDLErepairhome . Please help us get more people to this page. We need all the help we can get.

Thank you!

Acknowledgements

Colegio De La Estrella would like to thank three kind-hearted youths who volunteered to create a very meaningful video for this campaign. To Ms. Mara Muceros Duallo, Ms. MiChie Taguibao and Mr. Brian Edward Harris – for the commitment, positivity, openness and know-how, thank you so much.

story:
"If you think education is expensive, try ignorance."  Derek Bok 

Forced to climb the barriers of extreme poverty, pervasive childhood pregnancy, and an inadequate learning environment, two out of three Tanzanian schoolchildren drop out before they reach secondary school. 

This Christmas, help Marissa give Tanzanian youth another reason to stay in school! Currently, she is working with six schools (five primary and one secondary) around the town of Songea that have unusable blackboards—it is nearly impossible for the students to read what is written on them. 

It only costs $5 USD to rebuild each of these blackboards to new condition. Marissa plans to refurbish each herself, working alongside the students from each respective school. But, she needs your help buying the blackboard paint and supplies.

In her own words, “It’s is a fairly inexpensive project that would impact thousands of students in my ward. Everyone is already excited and can’t wait to sling some paint!”

Please help us raise money and build a brighter future for thousands of Tanzanian youth!

 

Details:

6 schools

42 classrooms

84 blackboards

thousands of Tanzanian schoolchildren!
